To ensure the WAN port on the Pepwave Mini is activated when connecting it to a Starlink adapter via Ethernet, it is necessary to have the latest firmware version installed. Prior to version 8.3, a license was required to enable the WAN port functionality.

To troubleshoot a non-functioning WAN port on an older Pepwave Max BR1, it is suggested to use a small switch between the Pepwave device and the Starlink connection. Additionally, ensuring that the Starlink is set to router mode can help, as this allows the Starlink to provide an IP address independently of the dish, which may assist in establishing a connection.

The user experienced issues with the WAN port on an older Pepwave Max BR1, which did not establish a connection with either a Starlink connection or a cable modem, despite attempts to reset the device. The user later upgraded to a MAX BR1 Pro 5G, which successfully connected to Starlink without issues. It is suggested that the WAN port on the older model may have been defective or unable to negotiate a connection with the Starlink system. The user utilized a MEAN WELL DDR-120A-48 power over Ethernet (POE) adapter tuned to 50V along with standard Starlink cabling for the connection.
To configure two VLAN WANs on a Pepwave BR1 Pro, a license purchase is required to enable this functionality.

When using a Pepwave router with external antennas, the signal is broadcast from the location of the antennas. To ensure WiFi is strong inside a campervan, it is advisable to use indoor WiFi antennas instead of connecting the outdoor antenna cables. If the router supports multiple access points, one can be placed inside the van and another outside for flexibility in coverage.

To set up a Pepwave BR1 Max Mini 5G for an event using hotel WAN as the primary connection and a SIM card as failover, ensure that the device is connected to an InControl2 account for management. In the router's admin interface, set the WAN connection to priority 1 and the cellular connection to priority 2 to configure the failover correctly.

Users have reported issues with routers that have integrated access points, such as the Surf Soho, particularly after upgrading to firmware version 8.1.2. A specific case was noted with a MAX BR1 mini, which remained in a 'cellular connecting' state for a week until rebooted. It is suggested to try rebooting the device and experimenting with turning off the Wi-Fi to see if it improves connectivity. As of now, firmware version 8.1.2 is still the latest available.

InControl2 is a centralized management platform for Peplink devices that allows users to manage multiple devices from a single web UI. It provides a dashboard displaying device status, internet connections, firmware information, and Wi-Fi configurations. Users can customize columns to view specific metrics, manage VLANs, routes, and create outbound policies for traffic shaping. The platform supports centralized IP management, firewall rules, and access control lists for devices across multiple sites. Additionally, it offers reporting features for device performance, connection tests, and bandwidth usage, along with notifications for various network events. Users can also manage firmware updates, device schedules, and geofencing capabilities to control Wi-Fi access based on location or time. Bulk configuration allows for the deployment of consistent settings across numerous devices, ensuring compliance and simplifying management.

InControl is a management platform for Peplink devices that provides a multi-tiered organizational structure, allowing users to manage devices at the organization, group, and device levels. Users can enable two-factor authentication, manage SIM cards, and create SIM pools for data utilization. The platform supports SpeedFusion configuration, which can be set at either the organization or group level, and allows for centralized firmware management across devices. Users can generate various reports, including device, Wi-Fi, and SIM card reports, and utilize features such as connection tests for performance monitoring. InControl also facilitates user management, including setting idle timeouts for compliance and customizing organization settings such as logos and addresses. Additionally, it provides warranty and license management, including the issuance of FusionHub licenses.

To enable GPS forwarding on a Peplink router, access the advanced menu and select miscellaneous settings, then click on GPS forwarding. Check the enable box to expand the menu, and input the destination IP address or hostname along with a port number, which can be any number that the server accepts. Choose between UDP or TCP, with UDP being the default. The reporting interval can be set to one second or adjusted to a longer interval, such as five seconds for stationary reporting. Optionally, a vehicle ID can be added to modify the reporting format. After configuring the settings, click Save and then apply changes. The GPS data will begin streaming to the specified destination once the changes are applied.

The Pepwave Max BR1 Mini is a popular cellular router that requires proper SIM card installation and configuration for internet connectivity. Users should ensure the SIM card is correctly inserted, activated with the carrier, and compatible with the device's hardware revision. Troubleshooting steps include checking the cellular LED status, testing antennas, and confirming signal strength. Users can access the router's web interface at 192.168.50.1 to check WAN connection status, APN settings, and firmware versions. If issues persist, users can download a diagnostic report from the device's status page for support. Firmware updates for both the router and cellular module can be performed through the web interface, ensuring the device operates with the latest software.

InControl 2 is Peplink's cloud-based SD-WAN network management service that allows users to monitor, configure, and troubleshoot Peplink devices remotely. Users can set up an InControl 2 account by signing up at incontrol2.peplink.com, creating an organization and group name, and adding device serial numbers. Configurations can be applied to individual devices or groups, and users can access remote web admin for advanced settings. The platform provides various reporting options, including device reports, Wi-Fi reports, WAN quality reports, and bandwidth usage reports, which help in monitoring performance and identifying weak signal areas. Additional features include user management at the group or organization level and event logs for monitoring WAN connection history.

The video discusses the installation process for a Pepwave MBX router and Starlink antennas in a mobile health clinic vehicle. The setup involves dual power inputs: a 12-volt DC power source for the MBX while driving and an AC power source from a generator for both the MBX and Starlink when stationary. The installation includes drilling holes for power cables and antenna mounts, ensuring no interference with existing electrical wiring or air conditioning vents. The use of Liquid Nails for securing the antenna box to the roof is highlighted, emphasizing the importance of proper sealing to prevent leaks while ensuring that screws are not overtightened to avoid stripping.

The Transit Duo router is being installed in a Jeep Gladiator, utilizing a 12-volt power source tapped from a Bluetooth speaker charger. The installation involves connecting the GPS and cellular cables, as well as the built-in Wi-Fi. The router features dual Cat 6 modems, allowing for bonding with two SIM cards for enhanced connectivity. Velcro is used for mounting the router, enabling easy removal for maintenance. The setup includes a SpeedFusion configuration, which allows for bonded cellular and Wi-Fi connections, enhancing overall internet speed and reliability in the vehicle.

The video discusses the integration of Starlink antennas with Peplink routers, highlighting the advantages of the high-performance Starlink dish for mobile applications. The high-performance dish allows direct connection to Peplink without needing the Starlink router, simplifying installation and reducing wiring complexity. It offers better performance, faster speeds, and an improved field of view compared to the Gen 3 Starlink dish. The integration allows for failover capabilities between cellular and satellite connections, enabling users to manage multiple WAN connections through Peplink's dashboard, including the use of SpeedFusion for cellular bonding. The setup involves running Ethernet cables from the Starlink dish to the Peplink router, with options for roof installations and watertight cable solutions.

The video discusses the installation of a Starlink in-motion antenna designed for RVs, detailing the mounting process and integration with a Peplink router. The installation involves securing the antenna mount with lag screws, ensuring a watertight seal using Dicor, and routing the antenna cable to the power supply. The Starlink antenna is connected directly to the Peplink router, allowing it to serve as the primary internet source, which can manage multiple connections including LTE and Wi-Fi. The installation emphasizes the importance of proper alignment, sealing, and cable management to ensure optimal performance and reliability.

The Peplink InControl platform enhances network management by providing visibility into switch status, port activity, and connected devices. It offers features such as client reporting, configuration backup, firmware management, and scheduled power management for PoE ports. Users can manage multiple SSIDs and VLANs through the AP series management, enabling unified control over wireless access points. The system supports captive portals with customizable settings and quotas for guest networks. Additionally, Peplink's access points can mesh to extend wireless coverage, although throughput decreases with each hop. The SIM injector allows for convenient SIM card management by relocating SIM cards closer to the user, facilitating easier access and management without needing to climb to the antenna location.

When troubleshooting a Pepwave BR2 with two Starlink antennas, it is important to check if the antennas are running in bridge mode, as having both in NAT mode could lead to IP address conflicts on the same network. Testing the connectivity by disconnecting the working Starlink antenna to see if the non-connecting one can establish a connection is also recommended. Additionally, using separate switches for each Starlink antenna may be necessary for proper configuration, and switching the antennas to see if the issue persists with the same unit can help identify the problem.

In a configuration involving a Peplink 20X connected to a FusionHub (FH) with a profile set for Dynamic Weighted Balancing (DWB), there is an observation of WAN Smoothing being reported in the detailed graphs despite it not being enabled. The graphs show a consistent low rate of packets being sent for WAN smoothing, which raises questions about whether this is a rendering issue or a side effect of the DWB configuration. The expectation is that if WAN smoothing were operational, there would be more balanced traffic across multiple WAN links due to redundant packets being sent and received.

For optimal performance with the Pepwave 310 5G at outdoor events, using omni-directional antennas in urban areas is recommended, while directional antennas may be more effective in rural areas with weak signals. The 310 5G has one modem that requires a 2x MIMO antenna and another that requires a 4x MIMO antenna, suggesting the use of different antenna models for each modem. There is no built-in feature to automatically select the best SIM card based on bandwidth or latency; users must manually test and switch SIM cards to determine the best options, allowing time for the SIM switching process.

When using SpeedFusion Cloud with a Pepwave MBX and multiple tunnels, issues may arise with traffic routing and application connectivity. Specifically, Netflix may not connect due to potential IP blocking by Netflix on the SpeedFusion Cloud hub, which operates within AWS infrastructure. It is also important to ensure that the routing rules are properly configured and not conflicting with normal policy routing settings.

The availability of LTE-A on a WAN connection is generally not restricted by the SIM or data plan, as there are no known data plans that prevent the use of LTE-A. However, certain roaming agreements may limit connections to 3G even when 4G is available on the host network.

The availability of LTE-A on a MAX BR1Mk2 router is dependent on the cellular/mobile towers equipped by the carrier/ISP within range of the router's antennas. If the router can only connect to a single frequency band, it will display LTE instead of LTE-A. For example, if connected to Band 28 (700Mhz) at a significant distance from the tower, the modem may not be able to tune into other higher frequency signals, which limits its capability to show LTE-A. The presence of multiple signals from the same ISP is necessary for the modem to indicate LTE-A status.

Using a SIM card intended for a tablet in a router like the MAX BR1Mk2 may lead to limitations imposed by the cellular provider, such as lower data caps or restrictions to 3G connections. If a user is experiencing only LTE and not LTE-A on their WAN connection status, it could be due to the SIM card's compatibility or restrictions, especially if LTE-A is available on other devices in the same location.

The MediaFast 500 supports all 8 load balancing algorithms, contrary to the initial impression that it only supports 7. This indicates that the specifications for the MediaFast family may not be fully representative of its capabilities regarding load balancing algorithms.
In firmware version 3.6.0, the WDS (Wireless Distribution System) option is not supported. It is recommended to update to firmware version 3.6.1 to access this feature.

To access the WDS option in the AP tab, users may need to download firmware version 3.5.4 from the Peplink support downloads archive, ensuring that the firmware matches the hardware revision of their access point.

In firmware version 3.6 of Pepwave AP products, the WDS (Wireless Distribution System) option has been eliminated from the web interface, which has caused issues for users relying on this feature for connectivity in situations without Ethernet cabling. Users have expressed concerns about the lack of communication regarding this change, as the documentation still references the WDS feature, and they advocate for better transparency in release notes regarding feature changes in future firmware updates.
The throughput speed of the Peplink Balance 20 is dependent on the hardware revision and the firmware version. The current model supports a throughput of 150 Mbps when on the latest firmware.

The throughput speed of the Peplink Balance 20 can be either 100 Mbps or 150 Mbps, which may depend on the specific hardware version or firmware. The R6 model is expected to achieve the higher throughput of 150 Mbps.

The Pepwave Sure SOHO MK3 is experiencing connectivity issues with its 2.4 GHz SSID, where devices can connect for a few hours before losing the ability to connect, although the SSID remains visible. The 5 GHz band continues to function without issues. The firmware version 7.1.0 operates correctly, while version 8.0.0 appears to cause connectivity problems after a period of time.

The Pepwave Sure SOHO MK3 is experiencing connectivity issues with the 2.4 GHz SSID, which connects for a few hours before stopping connections, while the 5 GHz SSID remains accessible. The issue appears to be related to firmware version 8.0.0, as the device operates normally on firmware version 7.1.0. The problem may not affect all devices connecting to the 2.4 GHz network, indicating that it could be device-specific.

To reset the admin password on a Peplink Balance 305 or above, starting from firmware version 5.4, users can utilize the LCD panel by navigating to *Maintenance* > *Reset Admin Password*. This action will reset the admin password to the default value of 'admin', allowing users to log in and change it to a new password as needed.
To enable PoE output on the B30 Pro, a 48VDC power supply is required. It is not possible to use a 24VDC input power for this purpose, even if there are sufficient amps available.

The PoE options for Peplink devices, including the B30 Pro, are compliant with the 802.3af/at standards once activated with a suitable power supply. If using a proprietary PoE configuration, it is recommended to use the device's recommended PoE injector instead of relying on the standard PoE support.

It is possible to change the ports used for SpeedFusion/PepVPN on a Peplink device. This allows for configuration without the need for port forwarding on UDP 4500 if that port is already in use by another service. The specific ports for SpeedFusion/PepVPN can be customized to accommodate network constraints.

To create a VPN connection between two Peplink units, specifically the BPL 305 and BPL 310, users can refer to the Balance and MediaFast User Manual for Firmware 7, which is available for download on the Peplink website under the Support section.

The user is experiencing intermittent disconnections with a Tmobile 50GB SIM in their UBR, where the connection drops for about 10 seconds every 30 minutes. A firmware update has been performed on the UBR, but it is unclear if the cellular module has also been updated. The issue persists despite the health check not indicating a failure.

The firmware upgrade process for the SOHO MK3 HW1 to version 8.1.0 appears to be failing, as the device continues to display version 8.0.2 after rebooting, with no error messages logged during the upgrade attempts. The user has tried various methods including online, incotrol 2, and manual upgrades, but none have succeeded in updating the firmware.

After updating the firmware on a Pepwave SOHO MK3 from version 8.0.2 to 8.1.0, the device still displays version 8.0.2 after rebooting. This issue may be related to the current configuration preventing the auto-update. A potential solution involves downloading the current configuration, resetting the device to factory defaults, attempting the firmware upgrade again, and then restoring the configuration if the upgrade is successful.

To resolve the issue of a Pepwave SOHO MK3 not updating from firmware 8.0.2 to 8.1.0 after reboot, it is recommended to download the configuration, restore factory settings, log in to change the password, check for new firmware in the system firmware tab, download firmware 8.1.0, and then reboot. After the reboot, the configuration file can be uploaded, resulting in successful firmware operation.

The firmware update from 8.0.2 to 8.1.0 on the SOHO MK3 is not reflecting correctly after reboot, as it still shows firmware version 8.0.2. This issue has not been reported on the B30 model, indicating a potential problem specific to the SOHO MK3 firmware update process.

After updating the firmware on the SOHO MK3 from version 8.0.2 to 8.1.0, users are experiencing issues where the router crashes during upload speed tests, particularly when sustained upload speeds exceed 55 Mbps. This problem occurs consistently during speed tests and affects teleworking capabilities. The user has not enabled any new features from the update, and the firmware version still displays as 8.0.2 after rebooting.

After updating the firmware on the SOHO MK3 from version 8.0.2 to 8.1.0, the device continues to display version 8.0.2 after rebooting. Additionally, users report that running browser speed tests causes the SOHO MK3 to crash during the upload phase, particularly when sustained upload speeds exceed 55 Mbps. The device becomes unresponsive and requires a manual reboot to recover.

After attempting to upgrade the SOHO MK3 to firmware 8.1.0 from 8.0.2, users may encounter issues where the device still shows the previous firmware version after rebooting. Additionally, there are reports of receiving a 'not bootable' error when trying to upgrade to build 4941 of firmware 8.1, indicating potential compatibility or installation issues with the firmware upgrade process for the SOHO MK3.

When upgrading the firmware of the SOHO MK3 from version 8.0.2 to 8.1.0, a special firmware may be required if the upgrade does not reflect after rebooting. This issue has been noted specifically for the SOHO MK3 model and does not occur with the B30 model.

The firmware update from 8.0.2 to 8.1.0 on Surf SOHO Mk3 routers may fail when the devices are managed through InControl, as evidenced by multiple users experiencing issues with the update process. In contrast, a Surf SOHO Mk3 that was not connected to InControl successfully updated to firmware 8.1.0 on the first attempt. Users are considering whether to use a special firmware version or inquire about newer firmware options to resolve the update failures.

To troubleshoot a Pepwave MK2 that is unable to obtain an IP address with an AT&T SIM card, it is suggested to first test the SIM card in another hotspot device to confirm its functionality. Additionally, on the BR1, changing the band selection to LTE only or using a custom band selection while disabling the currently connected WCDMA Band 5 may help establish a connection to an LTE band.

To forward ports on a Peplink Balance 1350 hardware version 2 running firmware 7.1.0 for external access to services like a PBX, users can refer to the user manual for detailed instructions, specifically on page 137 of the manual version 6.3.3.

The Peplink ONE allows users to view MAC addresses of connected devices and monitor active sessions under the Status > Active Sessions section. Additionally, there are guides available for blocking BitTorrent traffic, which can help in managing unauthorized downloads within a network.
With a Pepwave device, it is possible to see the MAC addresses of users connected to the network and to block BitTorrent traffic using the Content Blocking feature.

The Peplink ONE allows users to view the MAC addresses of devices connected to the network by mousing over the particular session, but this information is only available for active sessions. This capability can assist in identifying users engaging in specific activities, such as BitTorrent downloads, although the response does not explicitly confirm the ability to block such traffic.

Using a Peplink device, it is possible to implement content filtering to block BitTorrent users, which can help reduce network data usage and demonstrate compliance with legal usage. This setup allows for fair usage among all users in a network, and it can assist in managing network activity effectively.

A Peplink ONE device can be used to monitor network activity, including the ability to see MAC addresses of connected users. It is possible to block BitTorrent traffic, which can help prevent copyright infringement issues. However, the ability to view MAC addresses and user activity prior to blocking specific traffic depends on the configuration and capabilities of the Peplink device in use.

A Peplink router can be used to manage internet access in a mobile home park, including the ability to set up a Captive Portal for user authentication and data management. This can help in identifying users and controlling access. Content filtering features can also be utilized to block specific applications like BitTorrent. However, tracking MAC addresses and user activity may require ongoing administrative effort, especially as users change devices. Keeping the router firmware updated is recommended for optimal performance.

A Peplink device can provide visibility into the MAC addresses of devices connected to its network, including those behind a Ubiquiti Nano Station that is rebroadcasting the Wi-Fi signal. However, the ability to block BitTorrent traffic specifically may depend on the capabilities of the Peplink device and its configuration. To monitor traffic and potentially block specific users, the MAC address of the Ubiquiti Nano Station may need to be added to the Peplink controller for proper management and oversight of the network traffic.

The Pepwave MAX-BR1-MINI-LTE-E-T may experience slow internet speeds due to its limited support for mobile carrier frequencies compared to newer mobile devices. The user has configured the router with specific settings for their Vodafone Australia SIM, including NAT routing mode, automatic DNS, and LTE-only mode, but the speed issue persists despite these configurations. Health check settings are also configured, but the relevance of these settings to the speed issue is uncertain.

The Pepwave Max MAX-BR1-MINI-LTE-E-T is experiencing slow internet speeds of less than 1MB/sec with a Vodafone Australia SIM, while a Samsung Galaxy S6 connected to the same network achieves speeds of 80MB/sec download and 30MB/sec upload. The modem is set to LTE Only mode, with APN configured as live.vodafone.com and other settings such as NAT routing mode and automatic DNS. Health check settings are configured with SmartCheck, a timeout of 5 seconds, and an interval of 10 seconds. IP Passthrough is enabled, and idle disconnect is unchecked, but the modem's performance remains significantly lower than expected.

The Balance 20 and 30 routers have the same technical specifications, with the primary difference being that the Balance 30 includes an additional WAN port. The Balance 210 offers advantages such as support for a greater number of users, a more extensive list of Outbound Load Balancing options (7 options compared to 5 on the 20/30), and increased VPN capabilities not available on the 20 or 30 models. All models support multi-WAN configurations and can accommodate various internet connections including cable, DSL, and 3G/4G.

Both the Peplink Balance 20 and Balance 30 can be configured for 2 Ethernet connections, while the Balance 30 supports 3 Ethernet connections. Additionally, both models allow for 1 USB 3G/4G connection, which can be set up for backup use through Outbound Policy or WAN status. Users can also implement a bandwidth cap on the USB/Mobile connection to disable it upon reaching a monthly data allowance.

If a Peplink Balance X20 router is found to be registered to someone else upon setting up InControl2, it is recommended to return the router for a refund and order a new one from a seller that is shipped and sold by Amazon or an authorized reseller to ensure proper registration and warranty coverage.

To resolve issues with Apple/iOS devices not detecting an AirPrint HP Printer on networks using a Peplink Balance, ensure that Layer2 isolation is not enabled, as this could block communication between devices. Additionally, check the Internal Firewall rules on the Peplink Balance to ensure they are not preventing the detection of the printer by the iOS devices.

In a network configuration involving PepLink Balance 305 devices connected to a Balance 508 via IP Sec VPN tunnels to Azure, it is noted that IP Sec tunnels do not typically advertise their routes through second hops. To enable connectivity from satellite sites to Azure, a static route for the Azure subnet can be added on the satellite devices, pointing to the Balance 508. Additionally, firewall configurations on both the satellite sites and Azure may need to be reviewed to ensure they allow the necessary traffic exchange.

To enable connectivity from PepLink Balance 305 devices to Azure through a Balance 508, static routes can be configured on the Balance 305 for the Azure subnet, using the Balance 508 as the gateway. Additionally, the Azure configuration should include a static route for the Balance 305 subnet, also using the Balance 508 as the gateway. It is important to ensure that firewall rules on both ends permit this routing to function correctly.

As of the 2.8.4 release, InControl2 allows users to change the handshake port from the device level overview page, which may help in configuring PepVPN correctly when multiple Peplink devices are behind a single firewall and experiencing port forwarding issues.

In a setup with two Peplink devices behind a single firewall, port forwarding configurations are critical for enabling PepVPN connections. For Balance #1, UDP port 4500 and TCP port 32015 should be forwarded, while for Balance #2, UDP port 4501 and TCP port 32016 should be forwarded. However, if port 32015 is also forwarded to Balance #2, it will disrupt the connection for Balance #1. The PepVPN setup can be managed through InControl2, and while the default Data Port can be changed, the Handshaking port remains fixed, which may cause issues in connectivity if not configured correctly.

The Balance 300 router supports a maximum throughput of 20mbps per user, despite having three WAN connections each capable of 100mbps. This means that while the total potential speed from the WAN connections is 300mbps, the router's limitations restrict the actual usable speed to 20mbps per user, indicating that the additional bandwidth from the WAN connections is not utilized effectively.

When using RADIUS for authentication on Pepwave BRMini and BRMAX devices, the client IP address reported to the RADIUS server is that of the Pepwave Balance One, which acts as a VPN concentrator. This behavior complicates the assignment of admin rights to the Mini's and MAX's, as all requests appear to come from the same IP address. The setup involves the MiniMax devices connecting to the Balance on the WAN side, with the LAN side disabled, and traffic routing through multiple firewalls to an NPS server. NAT is turned off in this configuration, which is expected to allow individual device IPs to be reported, but the current behavior suggests otherwise.

When using RADIUS for authentication on Pepwave BRMini's and BRMAX's, the client IP address reported to the RADIUS server is the IP address of the Pepwave Balance One, which acts as a VPN concentrator. This issue arises even when NAT mode is disabled on both the Balance and the BR1Max devices. Other tools can correctly identify the source IPs of devices behind the BR1Max's, indicating that the configuration is minimal and primarily focused on cellular VPN functionality, with OSPF and SNMP enabled for accurate device IP reporting.

The Balance 30 router is experiencing a flashing red LED status light, which may indicate a hardware issue potentially caused by a thunderstorm. The user has attempted to reset the device using a paper clip without success. It is suggested to open a support ticket with Peplink for further assistance and to verify the condition of the device. Additionally, grounding of the equipment is mentioned as a consideration for protection against electrical surges.

In the event of potential lightning damage to networking equipment, it is advisable to replace all affected devices, including DSL modems, balance routers, and wireless links. Implementing lightning protection on all connection points is crucial, including power supplies, DSL/PSTN lines, Ethernet connections, and coaxial connections. Recommended products for lightning protection include Belkin Mains Surge Arrestors for power, carrier-approved surge arrestors for DSL/PSTN, Transtector and Cambium Networks for Ethernet, and Times Microwave for coaxial connections. Proper grounding of these devices is essential to divert surges away from the equipment, and failure to implement adequate lightning protection may void warranties and affect insurance claims.

The Balance 30 router is experiencing a flashing red LED status light, indicating a potential issue, possibly related to the xDSL modem that appears to be dead. The router can be rebooted, but it only shows a solid red light for about 60 seconds before flashing again. Resetting the device using the reset button has not been successful. There is a question regarding grounding the Balance 210, specifically whether it is recommended to connect a wire from the ground screw on the Balance 210 case to the ground pin of an outlet, especially when using a UPS that lacks a separate ground screw.

A self-hosted version of InControl2 (IC2) is available for managing Peplink devices, but it still requires a web browser for access. This privately hosted IC2 can be obtained through a local Authorized Peplink Partner and offers similar management capabilities as the public cloud version. To manage devices across different locations, the IC2 Private instance must be hosted on a server with public access, although it is recommended to use Peplink's publicly hosted IC2 unless specific security requirements necessitate a private setup.

There is a known issue with sorting the Download and Upload columns in the Client list of the Status section on the Balance One Core running firmware version 7.1. This sorting issue will be addressed in the upcoming firmware version 7.1.1, which is tentatively scheduled for release in late April.

There is a known issue with the sorting functionality in the 'Status: Client list' feature of the Peplink Balance One Core running firmware version 7.1, where sorting by Download or Upload does not correctly reorder the rows. A beta version 7.1.1 has been released to the partner community, and engineering is evaluating the timing for a production-grade firmware release that will address this UI fix.

A special firmware build is available to fix a user interface issue with sorting the Download and Upload columns in the Client list on a Balance One Core running firmware version 7.1. The specific download link for the firmware is provided for users to resolve the sorting problem.

In version 7.1 of the Balance One Core, a bug related to sorting the 'Status: Client list' by Download or Upload columns has been fixed. This bug previously affected the ability to accurately sort and identify the top talkers during network congestion, which is a critical step in network management.

The firmware version 7.1 for various Peplink models, including Balance 20/30, Balance 210/310, Max 700/HD2, SOHO MK3/BR1 MK2, and others, is available for download. Specific firmware files for these models are provided, indicating that the firmware engineers have created updates for multiple devices.

To troubleshoot a non-functioning Bandwidth log on a Pepwave 580 HW 1 running firmware 5.4.10, first check for time sync failures in the Status > Event Log. If there are no time sync issues, upgrading to the latest firmware version may be necessary to resolve the problem.

In a lab environment with a B310 and B1350 running firmware version 7.0.1, traffic is intended to be split across three links based on source/destination policies. However, the second and third tunnels are inactive, and traffic is defaulting to route 1, indicating that the policies are not functioning as expected. The placement of the routing rules may affect their behavior, with a suggestion that they should be positioned below the PepVPN route section. Additionally, failure detection settings were adjusted to minimize traffic across the links, with only minimal ping traffic being sent.

It is not possible to use LAN ports as WAN ports on the Peplink Balance 20. For users needing more WAN ports, the Peplink Balance One can be used along with a license key to convert LAN1-3 into WAN ports, allowing for a total of 5 WAN ports.

In a network setup where a Pepwave B210 router is used to bridge two separate LANs (198.42.231.0/24 and 198.42.232.0/24), it is important to ensure that the B210 is configured correctly for traffic routing. If NAT is enabled on the B210's WAN1, devices on LAN B can communicate with LAN A, but devices on LAN A will not be able to initiate communication with LAN B unless the B210 has a live NAT session. To facilitate communication from LAN A to LAN B, IP forwarding should be set on the B210's WAN1, allowing the B210 to forward traffic directly to devices on LAN B without relying on NAT sessions.

To bridge two separate LANs, a static route should be configured on the primary router (380) to allow communication between the two subnets. The static route should direct traffic for the 198.42.232.0/24 subnet to the WAN1 IP of the bridging router (210), which is set to 198.42.231.242. Additionally, the firewall settings on both routers must allow traffic between the subnets. An alternative solution is to configure an unused WAN port on the 380 as a LAN port for the camera subnet, which could simplify the setup by allowing direct communication between the two LANs without the need for the second router.

To bridge two separate LANs, ensure that the primary LAN router (380) has a static route configured for the secondary LAN (198.42.232.0/24) pointing to the WAN1 address of the bridging router (210) at 198.42.231.242. The bridging router (210) should be configured with its WAN1 connected to the primary LAN and functioning as a DHCP server for its own LAN (198.42.232.0/24). Devices on the primary LAN should have their gateway set to the primary router's address (198.42.231.124) to facilitate communication with devices on the secondary LAN. If communication fails, further diagnostics such as ping tests and traceroutes should be conducted to identify connectivity issues.

To bridge two separate LANs using a Pepwave 210 router, the WAN1 of the 210 should be configured with an IP address on the primary LAN, and it should have a static route set on the primary LAN router (380) pointing to the 210's WAN1 address for the secondary LAN. The 210 acts as a DHCP server for its own LAN, allowing devices to acquire IP addresses. However, if devices on the primary LAN cannot communicate with devices on the secondary LAN, it may indicate an issue with the static route configuration or firewall settings. The static route should specify the correct destination network and gateway for proper routing between the two LANs.

To bridge two separate LANs using a Pepwave 210 router, the WAN1 of the 210 should be configured with an IP address within the primary LAN's subnet, and a static route should be added on the primary LAN router (380) pointing to the 210's WAN1 address for the secondary LAN's subnet. The 210 acts as a DHCP server for its own LAN, allowing devices connected to it to acquire IP addresses. However, communication issues may arise if the static route is not functioning correctly or if there are firewall rules preventing traffic between the two subnets.

To bridge two separate LANs using a Peplink Balance 210, ensure that the WAN1 port of the 210 is connected directly to the LAN of the primary router (Balance 380) without any switches in between. A static route should be configured on the Balance 380 for the 198.42.232.0/24 network pointing to the 210's WAN1 IP address (198.42.231.242). If communication issues persist, testing connectivity by pinging a known IP address from the Balance 380's LAN interface can help diagnose the problem.

To bridge two separate LANs, a static route was added on the primary LAN router (380) for the secondary LAN (198.42.232.0/24) pointing to the WAN1 address of the bridging router (210) at 198.42.231.242. However, communication issues arose due to an Untangle anti-spam/firewall device between the primary router and the LAN, which required configuration to permit access to the secondary LAN.

To monitor WAN link status using SNMP on a Peplink device, the private MIB is utilized, but it may not provide the link status when the internet connection goes down, only showing traffic statistics. A SNMP walk can reveal various OIDs related to the device, including its identification and interface details. However, specific OIDs for WAN link status may not be present, indicating a limitation in monitoring capabilities for link status directly through SNMP.

To monitor WAN link status using SNMP on Peplink devices, it is important to use the correct MIB file for the firmware version. For 5.x firmware, the appropriate MIB can be downloaded from Peplink's website at the provided link. This MIB should contain the necessary information to track WAN connectivity status, including LINK DOWN notifications.

To prevent communication between Branch A and Branch B in a PepVPN setup, specific firewall rules should be implemented to restrict access between the two branches. This involves configuring the appropriate settings on the Pepwave devices to ensure that traffic is not allowed between the two branch networks.

To prevent communication between Branch A and Branch B in a PepVPN setup, it is important to ensure that the devices are running the current 6.2.0 firmware. If the issue persists after confirming the firmware version, it is recommended to create a support ticket for further assistance.

To connect a Peplink Balance e30 to an ADSL connection, the DSL router should be configured in Bridge mode to allow the Peplink to handle the PPPoE authentication. If the DSL router is set to authenticate, the Peplink WAN must be configured to either specify an IP address or to automatically obtain an address from the DSL router.

To establish a successful PepVPN site-to-site connection between two Pepwave UBR devices, one device must act as the hub, requiring inbound routing on TCP port 32015 and UDP port 4500. Each device must have the PepVPN ID of the other device or the remote peer's device serial number. The connecting devices must also have the public IP address of the hub device. While using InControl can simplify the setup process, manual configuration is also possible.

The Pepwave MAX 4E25 can run hot, which is often considered normal for the device. However, if it is overheating to the point of malfunction, it is advisable to monitor the temperature using a temperature gun or check the readings from the admin panel. Proper placement of the device is also important to prevent overheating.

Overheating issues can occur with Pepwave devices like the MAX 4E25 and MAX Transit Duo, particularly in enclosed spaces such as cabinets in travel trailers where ambient temperatures can exceed 100F. Users have reported that devices become very hot to the touch and may stop functioning when temperatures rise, especially in warm conditions. To mitigate overheating, it is recommended to improve ventilation in the cabinet and consider external cooling solutions. Additionally, devices under heavy load, such as those using SpeedFusion to bond multiple cellular and Wi-Fi connections, may be more prone to overheating.

The Pepwave MAX 4E25 can experience overheating issues, particularly when used in confined spaces or during hot weather, which can lead to operational failures. Users have reported that devices may struggle with cellular connectivity under these conditions, indicating a potential need for improved ventilation or alternative placement to mitigate heat buildup.

The Pepwave MAX 4E25 may experience overheating issues, which can lead to operational failure and safety concerns. While some users report that certain temperatures, such as 109F, are normal for devices like the AP AC mini, temperatures that cause burns indicate a malfunction. If the device is running excessively hot, it is advisable to seek a solution or consider returning the unit for safety reasons.

To address overheating issues with the Pepwave MAX 4E25, it is suggested to use a cabinet cooling fan to maintain a lower temperature. A specific model of a cooling fan with a manual switch for high, low, and off settings is recommended, which can help in cooling the device effectively during operation.

The Pepwave MAX 4E25 may experience overheating issues, which can be exacerbated by the power source used. One user reported using a 12V power source wired directly to the device via a barrel plug instead of the console connector, raising concerns about whether this method contributes to excessive heat. The case temperature was noted to reach 106°F in a closed cabinet at room temperature of 70°F, indicating a significant temperature increase that could lead to device malfunction.

To resolve the 'weak security' message on Apple devices when connecting to a Pepwave Max Duo, the SSID security settings should be edited to change the security policy from WPA2 to WPA3 for improved authentication.

InControl2 (IC2) provides options for managing the admin password of Pepwave devices, including the MAX-BR1-LTE-E and MAX-BR1-ENT-LTEA. Users can choose between three main password management options: 'Device managed', where the password is controlled from the device UI and not overwritten by IC2; 'Assign a random password for each device', where IC2 pushes a unique random password to each device, overwriting any locally set password during the next heartbeat; and 'Assign a shared password for all devices', where a defined password is pushed to all devices in a group, also overwriting any local settings. This management structure can lead to issues when switching between local and remote access, as local password changes may be overwritten by IC2.

When using Peplink MAX-BR1-LTE-E and MAX-BR1-ENT-LTEA devices, changes made to the admin password via InControl can lead to issues with local access. Specifically, if the admin password is set from InControl, it may revert to a default or random password upon logging back into InControl, causing local access attempts to fail. This behavior is linked to a two-minute heartbeat mechanism that overwrites local changes, indicating that InControl manages certain settings. It is suggested that the change password functionality be restricted when InControl is active to prevent confusion.

When IP passthrough is enabled on a Pepwave BR1 device, it is possible to manage the device from the LAN side. A PC connected to the BR1's LAN interface can access the admin interface using the IP address 10.120.12.186. Additionally, if a router is connected to the BR1's LAN, devices connected to that router can also manage the BR1 using the same IP address.
query: How can InControl2 be leveraged for centralized management, configuration, monitoring, and security of multiple Pepwave or Peplink devices, and what are some limitations or important considerations to keep in mind?
answer: InControl2 (IC2) is Peplink's cloud-based management platform designed to provide centralized configuration, monitoring, and security for fleets of Pepwave and Peplink devices. Through a multi-tiered organizational structure, users can manage devices at the organization, group, and device level, applying configurations such as VLANs, SSIDs, firewall rules, and SpeedFusion settings in bulk. IC2 supports reporting on device performance, bandwidth usage, Wi-Fi quality, WAN status, and SIM data utilization, and enables remote troubleshooting and firmware management. Security is enhanced through mandatory two-factor authentication and options for centralized admin password management. IC2 can also manage captive portals and geofencing, and can be self-hosted for organizations with specific security requirements. However, users should be aware that certain device settings (such as admin passwords) may be overwritten by IC2, potentially causing confusion if local and remote management are mixed. Firmware update processes may also be affected when devices are managed by IC2. Additionally, limitations exist for some features based on device hardware or firmware version, and local access may be restricted if IC2 is actively managing the device. Careful planning is needed to avoid configuration conflicts and ensure intended functionality across all devices.

citations.claim: InControl2 is a centralized, cloud-based management platform for Peplink/Pepwave devices, supporting configuration, monitoring, and reporting across multiple devices.
IC2 allows bulk deployment of settings such as VLANs, routes, firewall rules, and outbound policies to multiple devices or groups, ensuring consistent configuration and compliance.
IC2 supports reporting on device performance, bandwidth usage, Wi-Fi status, WAN quality, and SIM card data utilization.
Security is enhanced in IC2 by mandatory two-factor authentication for all managed customers, with no reported compromises among managed users.
IC2 supports centralized firmware management, device scheduling, geofencing, and captive portal management, and can be used to manage SSIDs and VLANs for unified Wi-Fi across locations.

IC2 allows for centralized password management, with options to assign random, shared, or device-managed admin passwords, which may overwrite local settings and cause local access issues if not coordinated.
IC2 can be self-hosted for organizations with special security or privacy requirements, but otherwise Peplink recommends using the public cloud version.

When devices are managed by IC2, certain operations such as firmware upgrades or password changes may behave differently, and users have reported firmware update failures or settings being overwritten if local and remote management are not coordinated.
Users should plan configurations carefully to avoid conflicts between local and centralized management, being aware of settings that IC2 will overwrite or control.
IC2 supports SIM management, SpeedFusion configuration, reporting, and user management at multiple levels, allowing for detailed control over device groups and organizational settings.

context_docs_list: Peplink devices have been discussed in terms of their support for 5G in both NSA (Non-Standalone) and SA (Standalone) modes. However, the specific availability of SA bands may not be reflected in the Band Selection dropdown menu for certain devices, such as the HD1 Dome 5G running firmware version 8.3.0 RC3.

The Peplink Max 5G can spoof the IP addresses of multiple modems while uploading data to a streaming server, making it appear to the destination service that all data is coming from the same IP address. To achieve this, the Peplink device would need to round robin the packets, sending them out over each interface in turn.

Peplink's SpeedFusion Bonding technology allows for the aggregation of multiple internet connections, enabling data uploads over several modems while presenting a single source IP address to the streaming server. However, IP spoofing is not a viable method for achieving this, as it does not manage the underlying application streams effectively.

The Peplink Max 5G can aggregate bandwidth using SpeedFusion VPN, which is beneficial for managing multiple WAN links for reliability and bandwidth during live video streams. However, it is important to note that bandwidth over cellular connections fluctuates constantly, so it is not simply a matter of summing the total bandwidth from multiple modems.

Carrier aggregation (CA) can drop from a maximum of 5 bands to just 2 bands on Peplink hardware, such as the MAX BR1 5G Pro and MAX BR2 5G Pro, after approximately an hour of use. This behavior has been observed across multiple carriers including Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile, and occurs regardless of whether the CA bands are set to Auto or manually selected. The drop in CA may be influenced by factors such as limitations of the Sierra Wireless modem or Peplink firmware, or external factors related to tower transmission. Stress tests indicate that once the CA drops to 2 bands, it does not increase beyond that level during repeated use.
The Peplink MAX BR1 Pro 5G has been certified for compatibility with AT&T's FirstNet service.
There is an upcoming release of a Peplink 5G Dome expected in June, which may be relevant for users considering upgrading their yacht's internet setup.

For a sailing boat installation of multi modem LTE, the Peplink Max HD2 Dome mounted at the top of a 45m carbon mast and the Peplink MBX Mini with two Mobility 40G antennas on the first spreader (10m high) are being compared. The MBX Mini's 4x4 MIMO antennas with higher effective gain are expected to provide better performance in terms of bandwidth and range compared to the HD2 Dome, particularly within 2.5NM/5km from cell towers, while still achieving a minimum of 500kbit/s for applications like WhatsApp calls and basic surfing/email. Load balancing capabilities may require specific service plans from Peplink, which could incur additional costs.

To purchase a spare power supply for a Peplink UBR modem, it is recommended to specify the exact model of the Peplink device to obtain the correct part number. Authorized Peplink partners can provide quotes and are able to sell the necessary components based on their authorized territory.

To address WAN DNS faults from the VSAT input on WAN 1, it is suggested to change the health check method to ping, targeting either the terminal or an internet address such as google.com. DNS lookups on VSAT can fail due to higher latency, and in many cases, it is recommended to disable the health check on VSAT entirely, as it is typically used only as a last resort.

Peplink products are favored for their SpeedFusion technology and load balancing capabilities across multiple WAN connections, which enhance network security and performance. Users appreciate the ability to stabilize livestream setups using SpeedFusion and FusionHub. However, Peplink devices are often considered too expensive and complex for the average consumer, who may prefer simpler, plug-and-play solutions available at retail stores.

To successfully route a UDP SRT stream through a SpeedFusion connection on a Pepwave MAX Transit Duo, changing the destination port from 10000 to 9000 resolved the issue. It is unclear why port 10000 was problematic, and there may be other port numbers that could also cause similar issues.

For bonding multiple cellular connections, the HD4 MBX supports four active cellular connections with 2x MIMO antennas using SpeedFusion technology, but it comes at a high cost of around $6000. An alternative approach discussed involves using two Max Transit DUO units, each with two different cellular connections, to potentially bond up to four active links, although it is unclear if this configuration is supported. Antenna requirements include high gain solutions for long-distance signal reception, with the Poynting 402 being noted as a good 2x2 option, while larger omni antennas with 4x4 configurations are lacking in the market. The Max Transit has a bonding limitation of significantly under 100 Mbps, which may not meet performance needs.

To resolve issues with the HD2 Dome not detecting the SIM card when using a SIM Injector, it is important to ensure that the HD2 Dome is running firmware version 8.1.0 and the SIM Injector is on firmware version 1.1.68. If problems continue after updating to the latest firmware, it is recommended to open a support ticket for further assistance.

The expiry date for licenses related to SpeedFusion Cloud is based on the Care plan (EssentialCare, PrimeCare, SmartCare, and TotalCare) rather than the date the license is issued or activated by the user.

To achieve bandwidth bonding using multiple SIM cards with a SIM Injector, the router must support multiple active SIM cards. The Peplink MAX BR1 only supports a single active SIM card, while models like the HD2 MBX support two active SIM cards, and the HD4 MBX supports four active SIM cards. Additionally, not all Peplink products are compatible with the SIM Injector.
The correct cable for the power port in question is identified by the part number ACW-638, which can be purchased through certified partners.

VoIP services over a Peplink MAX modem with Verizon should theoretically work since modems are generally agnostic to the data stream, including voice data. However, specific issues may arise depending on the VoIP provider and codec used. There are users in the USA successfully operating VoIP services over Verizon's network, indicating that it is possible to achieve functionality with the right setup.

The issue reported involves a recurring bug in firmware version 8.0.2, where SpeedFusion connections on B710 routers become stuck in an 'updating routes' state, particularly when the routers have a high number of connections. The problem is more prevalent on B710s with many connections, with instances of stuck connections increasing significantly as the number of connections rises. The only resolution is to reboot the router or disable and enable the profile on the affected end. Additionally, the setup involves route isolation, which should be enabled at the hub site to prevent inter-access between head offices, and the design includes OSPF Discontiguous Areas to manage route advertisement between different areas.

The Peplink MAX-BR1 currently does not have Class 1 Division 2 (C1D2) certification, which limits its sales potential in oil and gas sectors that require this certification. There is an ongoing effort to request the necessary certification for the MAX-BR1, and updates regarding certified products will be provided on the forum.

For a MAX-HD4-LTEA-W-T installed on a boat for worldwide travel, it is advised to consult with a knowledgeable Peplink supplier regarding compatibility and performance issues, especially since modem requirements can differ between Asia/Pacific and Europe/Americas. The HD4 model does not support modem upgrades, which may limit its effectiveness for global use. Alternatives such as the HD4 MBX, HD2 MBX, or BPL-SDX are recommended, as they allow for future upgrades of cellular modules. Specifications for the next generation Cat 18 modules in Hong Kong and Asia are currently unavailable.

In a high availability (HA) setup with two Peplink devices configured in Drop-In mode, the Peplink A and Peplink B are assigned IP addresses 192.168.1.2 and 192.168.1.3 respectively, with a virtual IP of 192.168.1.1. The failover process works initially, but after multiple tests, the internet becomes unavailable when the master Peplink recovers and resumes its role. It is suggested to ensure that the latest firmware is being used and to perform a trace route to identify any issues in the network path.

TotalCare is a service plan available only in North America that provides telephone support and advanced replacement for devices, along with an IC2 subscription. SmartCare also offers defective device replacement with advanced replacement for Dead On Arrival devices and includes an IC2 subscription. PrimeCare is a new service plan that includes an IC2 subscription, enhanced FusionHub licensing, and hardware warranty, but is limited to specific devices such as the Transit Mini and MAX Transit.
Spare parts such as sim card covers and screws for the Pepwave MAX-TST-DUO device can be purchased separately from suppliers like 5gstore.

The virtual SIM for remote provisioning is available on the Peplink HD2 Dome, which utilizes a SIM injector. The SIM injector is populated with physical SIM cards and connects to the HD2 Dome via Ethernet.

After upgrading a SpeedFusion Engine from firmware version 7.1 to 8.1.0, a "No SIM card detected" message appeared for both SIMs. A downgrade to 8.0.2 resolved the issue but resulted in an alert stating that the "Remote SIM Component not supported on this Firmware." To troubleshoot the 8.1.0 issue, it is suggested to perform the firmware upgrade again from 8.0.2 to 8.1.0 and check if the alert persists, and to use the "Reload SIM" option to see if it resolves the SIM detection issue.

After updating a SpeedFusion Engine from version 7.1 to 8.1.0, the dashboard displayed 'No SIM card detected' for both SIMs. A downgrade to version 8.0.2 resolved the detection issue but resulted in an alert stating 'Remote SIM Component not supported on this Firmware'. The standard SpeedFusion Engine has an integrated SIM, but the SIM card holders are on a separate internal board.

After updating a SpeedFusion Engine to version 8.1.0, a "No SIM card detected" error appeared for both SIMs, while downgrading to version 8.0.2 resulted in an alert indicating that the Remote SIM Component is not supported on that firmware. A potential troubleshooting step is to clean the SIM card to address possible contact issues with the SIM slot.

After updating a SpeedFusion Engine from version 7.1 to 8.1.0, the Dashboard displayed 'No SIM card detected' for both SIMs. A downgrade to version 8.0.2 resolved the issue but resulted in an alert stating 'Remote SIM Component not supported on this Firmware.' This indicates a potential compatibility issue with the firmware version 8.1.0 regarding SIM detection.

To activate a SIM card for a new BR1 MAX MK2, the IMEI number can be found on the device's box or obtained from the Peplink Partner from whom the device was purchased, as Peplink provides a method for Partners to look up the IMEI by serial number.

To troubleshoot poor signal strength on a MAX-BR1-LTE-US, it is suggested to compare the cellular bands that both the phone and the PepLink device are connecting to. It is important to select the PepLink device to connect to the same band as the phone, if available. Additionally, checking the actual signal strength readings on both devices, rather than just the bar indicators, can provide a clearer understanding of the connectivity issues.

When attempting to import a firewall rule set from a configuration file on a PepWave MAX BR1 Mini, an error message indicating failure to extract firewall rules may occur. To manage firewall rules by group policy rather than by device, it is suggested to enable the 'Manage Firewall Rules on Balance and MAX devices' option at the group level in the InControl2 Web Portal before importing the configuration file. If issues persist, contacting the InControl2 team for support may be necessary.

The Peplink ONE allows users to view the MAC addresses of devices connected to the network by mousing over the particular session, but this information is only available for active sessions. This capability can assist in identifying users engaging in specific activities, such as BitTorrent downloads, although the response does not explicitly confirm the ability to block such traffic.

Using a Peplink device, it is possible to implement content filtering to block BitTorrent users, which can help reduce network data usage and demonstrate compliance with legal usage. This setup allows for fair usage among all users in a network, and it can assist in managing network activity effectively.

After a router's warranty period, users can purchase an InControl2 (IC2) subscription for models like the Balance 20 and Surf SOHO, which provides access to IC2 but does not cover hardware warranty. An extended warranty can also be purchased for those who want both IC2 access and hardware coverage. The subscription is a more affordable option for IC2 manageability alone.

The Pepwave MAX 700 can create IPsec tunnels to compatible devices such as Cisco, Juniper, or Peplink devices, allowing for one tunnel per WAN connection. It supports failover configurations to maintain IPsec connectivity if one WAN goes down. For enhanced bandwidth utilization, a Peplink Balance device (such as Balance 580 or above) can be used at the main office to create a Site-to-Site VPN with the MAX 700, utilizing VPN bonding technology to combine the bandwidth of all Internet links. The Pepwave MAX 700 has 2 Ethernet interfaces, supporting up to two DSL links, while the Peplink Balance 310 or above supports at least three Ethernet interfaces and one USB port for additional 3G/4G connectivity.

In a Peplink One setup with multiple WANs, if devices assigned to a primary WAN are not failing over to secondary WANs during an outage, it may be due to priority settings on the dashboard that override outbound policy configurations. For the outbound policy priorities to function correctly, all WANs must be set to priority #1. Updating the firmware from version 8.1.3 to 8.2.0 did not resolve the issue of devices not switching to alternative WANs during an outage.

For a Peplink One with multiple WANs, if devices configured with a priority order are not failing over to secondary WANs during an outage, it is essential to ensure that a Health Check is configured on the affected WAN. Without a health check, the router will not detect the outage and will not initiate failover to other WANs, resulting in a loss of internet connectivity for those devices.

The Balance 305 device has a CMOS battery that may cause issues if it dies. It is recommended to keep the device under warranty with Peplink, as they can replace the battery through a Return Merchandise Authorization (RMA) process.

In a SpeedFusion tunnel configuration with two LTE connections of differing performance, the overall speed may be slower than the fastest bonded connection, resulting in only the average speed being reported rather than the total speed minus overhead. The upload limit may contribute to packet loss, and it is important to identify the source of any limits causing this issue, especially when no limits are configured.

The Standard Hardware/Software Warranty Policy indicates that if a device experiences problems within 14 days of purchase, a better arrangement should be made for replacement. However, if the device is reported after 14 days, the replacement may not be a new unit unless smart care was ordered at the time of purchase. It is also suggested that the device may not yet be registered with Peplink, which could affect warranty claims.

The Balance One Core router can use both WAN connections simultaneously through load balancing, which allows for seamless internet access without noticeable interruptions for most applications. However, if a conference call is in progress over WAN 1 and that connection fails, the call would drop unless SpeedFusion is enabled, which allows for uninterrupted transitions to WAN 2. SpeedFusion is a VPN technology that can be implemented between Peplink devices, and it can be set up in three ways: connecting Peplink hardware to another Peplink hardware, connecting Peplink hardware to FusionHub, or connecting to SpeedFusion Cloud. The latter is the simplest method for testing SpeedFusion. Users can create outbound policies and VLANs to manage traffic routing effectively, allowing specific traffic to utilize SpeedFusion while other traffic continues to use load balancing.

To troubleshoot issues with Windows 10 computers synchronizing clocks with time.windows.com while using a SpeedFusion connection to a FusionHub, it is important to ensure that UDP Port 123 is open, as it is required for NTP (Network Time Protocol). Testing with another NTP server outside of the country may also help identify the issue, which could potentially be related to firewall settings.

When experiencing issues with Windows 10 computers synchronizing clocks with time.windows.com over a SpeedFusion connection to a FusionHub, it is important to ensure that outbound traffic is allowed and that no outbound ports are blocked. The stateful firewall should permit the response to outbound NTP requests without requiring a specific inbound rule for NTP.

To prevent internet traffic from stopping when one WAN connection fails on a Balance One router, it is important to configure health check settings properly. The health check method should be set up to accurately detect when a WAN is down, as the current settings may still be receiving replies even when the WAN is not functioning. Additionally, WAN failures will be logged in the system log for further analysis.

Firmware upgrades for Peplink devices are provided for free regardless of the warranty status of the device, meaning users can continue to receive firmware updates beyond the initial one-year period without needing to purchase a support license.

The management of Peplink devices can be done through InControl2, which is a cloud-based management platform. It allows for the management of multiple devices, providing a centralized interface for configuration and monitoring.
To troubleshoot SpeedFusion connectivity problems, it is important to ensure that TCP port 32015 is open, as it is used for the 'handshake' necessary to establish the tunnel.

To regain web-based control of devices through InControl2 after the warranty period has expired, one can purchase an InControl subscription for 12 or 24 months (SKU: ICS-012, ICS-024). This subscription is applicable to various models including Balance 20, 30, 50, One, One Core, MAX On-The-Go, BR, Surf SOHO, AP One AC Mini, 300M, In-Wall, Flex, AP Pro, and FusionHub Essential and Pro. Devices that are out of warranty require an Extended Warranty, which is also available for 12 or 24 months. Additionally, SmartCare can be obtained to restore warranty status for out-of-warranty devices, potentially requiring a current diagnostic file.
The Peplink Balance 210 supports up to 10,000 concurrent NAT sessions. For detailed specifications, it is advisable to contact a local Peplink partner.

The Peplink Balance One (14D3) is experiencing intermittent loss of access to the LAN port (192.168.1.1) and is showing as offline in INControl2, despite the status LED and Wi-Fi indicators remaining green. Power cycling the device temporarily restores functionality for varying durations. Troubleshooting steps taken include changing the MTU settings to auto from 1440, upgrading firmware from 7.01 to 7.02, modifying the LAN IP address, and blocking all inbound connections. No new configurations were made prior to the issue arising, and the device is still under warranty until 2019.
TotalCare is a support policy offered by Peplink that is only available in North America.

SpeedFusion VPN is a suitable solution for aggregating multiple internet connections to enhance stability and reduce disconnects. It includes features such as Hot Failover, which automatically switches to another available connection during a failure, ensuring no downtime. WAN Smoothing addresses packet loss by sending extra packets that can be reconstructed, while also optimizing traffic to the connection with the lowest latency. Bandwidth Bonding combines multiple connections into a single high-speed connection, though it may not be necessary for all setups. It is important to note that SpeedFusion VPN requires Peplink devices on both ends of the tunnel for operation.

To establish remote access to a server through a Peplink modem using an L2TP VPN connection, the user should connect to the modem and then access the server by entering its LAN IP address. It is also important to ensure that the Mac is configured to route all traffic over the VPN connection to successfully reach the server.

The InControl2 (IC2) subscription is applicable only for specific Peplink products, including Balance models 20, 30, 50, One, One Core, MAX On-The-Go, BR, Surf SOHO, AP One AC Mini, 300M, In-Wall, Flex, AP Pro, and FusionHub Essential and Pro. For a Balance 710 with an expired warranty, it is recommended to purchase TotalCare or SmartCare instead.

For upgrading an old Peplink 310 HW 1 running firmware 4.8.3, it is noted that the device is unsupported by InControl2 and cannot be updated to the newest firmware version. The user successfully updated to firmware 5.2.12 but requires a license key to run newer versions. An unlock key for version 5.x can be provided if the serial number of the device is shared.

To obtain a firmware unlock key for a Balance 20 device, it is necessary to register the device on the Peplink website with the correct purchase date, which will sync the one-year warranty. Even if the device is out of warranty, the firmware unlock key can still be accessed via InControl by navigating to the device's management page.

When adjusting bandwidth management values on a device with firmware 3.5.2 build 1537, an error message may appear indicating an 'Invalid Default Interim Interval' with an allowed range of 60 to 2678400 seconds. If issues persist, a power cycle of the device is recommended as a troubleshooting step.
SpeedFusion bonding is not supported on the lower end Peplink models such as the 20, 30, and 50, although these models do support PepVPN.

To connect a client's Peplink devices to the InControl 2 (IC2) web portal, all devices must be under warranty or have an IC2 subscription, which is only available for smaller models. Devices such as the Balance 210 and above need to be put back into warranty to utilize IC2. Additionally, all devices must be running firmware version 6.x or higher to be recognized by IC2.

To upgrade the firmware of a Balance 20 to v6.x, users must obtain an unlock key from InControl2, which is associated with their registered account. Access to firmware downloads is limited to the version that corresponds with the current account status, and the unlock key is necessary for accessing newer firmware versions.

For aggregating bandwidth from multiple data cards, the Peplink MAX-700 and MAX-HD2 are suitable devices. The MAX-700 has 4 USB ports for connecting modems, while the MAX-HD2 features 2 integrated modems and 1 USB port. Load balancing can be achieved with a single unit, distributing network traffic across all available connections. For more advanced bonding on a per packet basis, multiple Peplink devices can be used in conjunction with a SpeedFusion VPN tunnel.

To upgrade a Balance 20 to the 6.1 firmware, the device must be under initial warranty to obtain an unlock key. However, a one-year extended warranty option is available for purchase. The upgrade to 6.1 firmware provides access to new features without needing to buy a new device. Upgrade keys are not required for other models like MOTG, BR1, and SOHO. A guide for upgrading to the 6.1 firmware is available on the Peplink website.

The user is seeking to renew their InControl 2 (IC2) subscriptions for their Peplink devices, specifically the MAX Transit and Transit Duo, which are no longer under warranty. They express concern over the potential elimination of the affordable IC2 only subscription option and inquire about the status of their PepVPN/SpeedFusion links if the subscription expires. The response suggests that the user should provide serial numbers for assistance with the renewal process.

The Pepwave MAX HD2 LTE is fully licensed for SpeedFusion VPN, requiring no additional license key for access. To utilize PepVPN, a bonded tunnel must be created from the HD2 to another Peplink appliance or through Peplink's hosted SpeedFusion Cloud service. Alternatively, users can host their own FusionHub appliance in the cloud, which requires licensing based on the number of remote connected devices, such as a 200 peer license for 200 delivery vehicles.

The PepLink HD4 MAX features cellular modems with a configuration of one MAIN port and one AUX (diversity) antenna port for each of its four modems, as indicated on the product page. This configuration is standard in many 4G/LTE modems, allowing for improved signal reception and redundancy.

To access the login page of a Peplink Max BR1 MK2, if the standard IP address 192.168.50.1 does not respond, it may be necessary to use the reset button located in a small hole on the device to restore functionality.

For live streaming at 1080p resolution on platforms like YouTube, Twitch, and Facebook, a minimum bandwidth of 8Mbit/s is required. The installation of a Peplink HD2 Mini or HD2 Dome is suggested to utilize both LTE radios for better connectivity. Setting up a SpeedFusion VPN may enhance reliability for live streaming, especially in a maritime environment.

Peplink IPsec only supports network-to-network connections with Cisco, Juniper, or Peplink devices. There is a successful setup of IPsec with a Cisco router, but challenges are faced when attempting to set up an IPsec tunnel with a Palo Alto device.

When using Peplink MAX-BR1-LTE-E and MAX-BR1-ENT-LTEA devices, changes made to the admin password via InControl can lead to issues with local access. Specifically, if the admin password is set from InControl, it may revert to a default or random password upon logging back into InControl, causing local access attempts to fail. This behavior is linked to a two-minute heartbeat mechanism that overwrites local changes, indicating that InControl manages certain settings. It is suggested that the change password functionality be restricted when InControl is active to prevent confusion.

To properly utilize MediaFast Content Caching on a Pepwave HD4, devices must be connected to the Native VLAN of the MediaFast, which is typically VLAN 0 or VLAN 1, depending on the network configuration. This allows for the installation of certificates necessary for caching functionality. The MediaFast will redirect the certificate download link to the router's IP address, enabling the installation process.

To resolve the issue of the missing 'Remote Sim Management' menu in the HD2 Dome and Remote SIM Injector, it is necessary to update the firmware of both devices. The recommended firmware for the HD2 Dome is version 8.0.1s015, and for the Remote SIM Injector, it is version 1.1.8. After updating, further updates to the HD2 Dome can be made to version 8.0.1 RC4 if needed. If problems persist after these updates, users should contact Peplink support or their local reseller for assistance.

The nominal output power of the Pepwave MAX HD2 (MAX-HD2-LTE-US-T) cellular modules is 23 dBm (+- 1 dB). The maximum antenna gain recommended by the FCC, including cable loss, should not exceed 4.0 dBi.

To configure a Peplink Max HD4 to use only the Europe-only SIMs while in Europe, roaming options can be set based on the Mobile Country Code (MCC). This ensures that the more expensive World SIMs do not connect while in Europe, as the SIMs will connect according to the country of origin.

If a connection is refused when trying to access a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, it is important to verify that the default IP has been changed from 192.168.50.1 to 192.168.25.1. Additionally, checking the IP address of the connected laptop or PC is crucial to ensure it is on the same subnet as the router for successful connectivity.

If a connection is refused when attempting to connect to a PepLink Max BR1 router at the IP address 192.168.25.1, one potential solution is to use the website http://whatsmyrouterip.com/ to help establish a connection through a web browser. This may assist in accessing the router's settings and performing a reset if necessary.

SpeedFusion VPN can be utilized with Pepwave devices such as the Max HD4 and Max HD2 over a cellular intranet, allowing for features like Hot Failover, WAN Smoothing, and Bandwidth Bonding, provided that both sites can communicate with each other. Hybrid setups are also possible regardless of whether the connection is private or public.

The MAX HD4 is capable of bonding multiple internet connections using SpeedFusion Bandwidth Bonding, which is a VPN technology. To achieve bandwidth bonding, a SpeedFusion VPN tunnel must be established to another Peplink SpeedFusion capable device or appliance, such as a Peplink Balance 305 or Peplink FusionHub located in a datacenter.

To achieve bonding of multiple SIM cards and a USB modem on a Pepwave MAX HD2 for streaming purposes, the SpeedFusion VPN Bandwidth Bonding functionality is required. The MAX HD2 supports this technology, allowing for the aggregation of WAN connections into a single high-throughput connection. The maximum throughput for SpeedFusion on the MAX HD2 is 100 Mbps without encryption and 60 Mbps with encryption. It is necessary to connect the MAX HD2 to a Peplink Balance 210, which should be located in a datacenter with a WAN connection speed that meets or exceeds the total bandwidth being bonded.
