Care should be taken to avoid including high latency connections in the bonding process, as they can negatively impact performance.

To address regular outages on the MAX BR1, it is recommended to upgrade the firmware to version 7.0.2, which may resolve stability issues. The firmware can be obtained from the Peplink support downloads page, where release notes are also available for further details.
For the MAX HD2 LTE IP67, the power connector part number is ACW-636. Additionally, the PoE injector for this device has a different part number, which is ACW-107.

For managing access points with a Pepwave MAX HD4, local AP management is a straightforward option, especially for users managing a limited number of devices. This approach allows for easier control without the need for utilizing the integrated AP controller of the router or the InControl2 setup.

The Pepwave Max 700 can merge connections to increase bandwidth, allowing multiple USB modems to be used simultaneously. By inserting four USB modems with 2 Mbps connections each, it is possible to achieve a combined bandwidth of 8 Mbps for tasks such as uploading to YouTube.

The Pepwave MAX On-The-Go (OTG) device performs session-based load balancing across multiple USB modems, allowing for up to four separate sessions or streams. However, it does not support bandwidth bonding, meaning that for a single session or stream, only one modem will be utilized at a time, limiting the speed to that of the individual modem.

To merge multiple USB dongle connections on a Pepwave MAX On-the-Go device, SpeedFusion technology can be utilized along with a third-party service. This allows for the aggregation of bandwidth from the connected modems, enabling the user to combine the speeds of the individual connections.
To create more than two IPSEC VPN links from a PepWave Max700 device, an additional PepVPN license is required. This license can be purchased from a Peplink Partner or through the Peplink Store.

For streaming live events in 720p, the Pepwave MAX-HD4-LTE is recommended as it comes with 4 embedded LTE/3G modems. Utilizing SpeedFusion VPN bonding technology allows for the combination of multiple connections, maximizing upload speed and providing redundancy in case one carrier drops off. This setup can help achieve the required upload speed of 3 to 4.5 Mbps for streaming.

The Pepwave MAX 700 supports SpeedFusion VPN bonding technology, which allows for site-to-site VPN connections. To utilize this feature effectively, another SpeedFusion-enabled device is required on the opposite end, or alternatively, a FusionHub server can be deployed at a data center or in the cloud, such as on Amazon AWS.

The output power levels for the 2.4GHz band on a Pepwave MAX HD2 are as follows: with Boost enabled, the power levels are Max - 27dBm, High - 24dBm, Medium - 21dBm, and Low - 18dBm. Without Boost enabled, the levels are Max - 18dBm, High - 15dBm, Medium - 12dBm, and Low - 9dBm. It is important to note that transmit power may vary based on the country.

The InControl 2 (IC2) subscription is not available for the Pepwave MAX HD2 devices. Instead, users need to purchase either a standard or smart care warranty for these devices. A list of devices eligible for IC2 subscription includes various models from the Balance series, MAX On-The-Go, Surf SOHO, AP One series, and FusionHub options.

The grey triangle indicator on the Peplink Max HD dashboard signifies that the SIM card is in roaming status. This can be associated with higher data charges, but normal traffic can still pass while in this state.

To broadcast TV from the field without satellite, a Balance router can be used to establish SpeedFusion connections between multiple MAX routers, depending on the model. For instance, a Balance 210 supports connections from 2 SpeedFusion peers, allowing for remote locations to connect. Utilizing SpeedFusion technology can enhance the broadcasting setup, and deployment diagrams are available to illustrate the configuration for effective broadcasting.

The MAX 700 can be used to bond multiple 4G MiFi dongles for live video streaming, but it is suggested that a PepLink Load Balancing router is needed at the office or data center for transferring the final upload. Concerns were raised about whether the Load Balancing router can be pre-configured for automatic operation without requiring an extra person for monitoring. Compatibility issues were mentioned regarding the MAX 700 with Huawei E303 USB Modem and Huawei E586 MiFi Dongle. User feedback indicated that the device may not effectively increase overall bandwidth when bonding multiple 4G devices, with some users reporting no significant improvement compared to using a single 4G device.

Peplink's SpeedFusion technology is used for bandwidth aggregation and can work with VPNs. It does not require a centralized VPN or bandwidth terminal server. The MAX On-The-Go model supports bandwidth aggregation as well as load balancing. Compatibility with USB modems from Huawei and ZTE using CDMA technology is not explicitly confirmed in the response, but further details can be found on the provided links.

To achieve bonded internet connections using the Pepwave Max 700 with multiple USB modems, it is necessary to have two devices on either end of the internet connections to utilize Peplink's SpeedFusion technology, which allows for packet breakdown, transmission over different links, and reassembly. Without this setup, the Max 700 can still provide benefits through optimal configuration of outbound load balancing algorithms, but it will not achieve true bonding. Speed tests may not accurately reflect the combined speed of all connections, as they typically only utilize one connection for testing.

When using a Pepwave Max 700 with multiple USB modems for bonded internet, the maximum speed achieved may be limited by the shared bandwidth of the cellular connections, especially if they are from the same carrier. To test the actual speeds of each modem, it is suggested to connect each modem to separate laptops and perform individual speed tests, followed by simultaneous tests to assess their combined performance.

To establish a point-to-point high-speed bonded link using two Pepwave MAX 700 units with four 3G USB modems each, it is feasible to achieve this setup with dynamic IPs, as indicated by successful SpeedFusion connections between similar devices. The setup includes configuring SpeedFusion on both devices, ensuring Dynamic DNS is operational, and verifying connectivity through ping responses. For load balancing internet access for users at both ends, the configuration allows for simultaneous internet access while maintaining the disaster recovery setup, as long as the necessary routing and firewall settings are correctly implemented.

To set up a point-to-point high-speed bonded link between two Pepwave MAX 700 units using 4 x 3G USB modems at each end, it is important to note that NetBios information does not travel across a Layer 3 VPN, so network drives should be mapped accordingly. The MAX_OTG_U4_SF is currently supported as a VPN endpoint device, and future firmware updates will allow for the termination of a SpeedFusion VPN tunnel between two MAX 700 units. Additionally, it is feasible to provide load-balanced internet access to users at both ends while maintaining the disaster recovery setup, as the DR servers sync at night and internet access is only needed during the day.

To achieve load balanced or bonded speeds for FTP/HTTP uploads using Pepwave MAX HD2 or MAX 700 routers with cellular modems, it is necessary to utilize SpeedFusion VPN bonding technology. This technology allows for the combination of multiple SIM cards to enhance upload speeds. A VPN Hub is required on the receiving end to reassemble the packets from the bonded connections, and the setup process is described as straightforward for users familiar with routers and IP configurations.

The Pepwave MAX Mobile router supports SpeedFusion VPN bonding, which allows for the aggregation of multiple WAN links such as 3G, 4G, and Wimax to connect to an enterprise network. With SpeedFusion bandwidth bonding, the combined bandwidth of two 3M connections can yield approximately 5.4M after accounting for system usage. To implement this solution, a Peplink Balance router is required at the headquarters or network operations center (NOC) to pair with the MAX Mobile router.

The Surf SOHO is listed as a legacy product on the Peplink website, indicating that Peplink is likely not producing any more units of this model, and once the current inventory is sold out, it may no longer be available.

Peplink products do support DFS frequencies, but they have DFS detection capabilities that will automatically disable DFS channels if a DFS source is detected nearby. The devices will change channels until the next restart in such cases.

InControl 2 is a remote management tool for Peplink devices, allowing users to configure their routers remotely after creating an account and adding the device. This feature is included as long as the device is under warranty, but can also be purchased separately if the warranty is not renewed. It is recommended to renew the warranty for continued access to this feature.

Although the AP One Flex is out of warranty, it is still possible to purchase an InControl 2 (IC2) subscription for the device. Users experiencing issues with warranty expiration should refer to the Peplink hardware warranty policy for further guidance.

For setting up wireless access across a site using multiple Pepwave Pro devices, utilizing InControl2 can simplify management of the devices. InControl2 allows for centralized control and can help in managing the network effectively, including transitioning from cloud management to local device management if needed. Users can also host their own instance of InControl2 within their network for more control.

InControl2 is a cloud-based device management, monitoring, and reporting tool designed for Peplink and Pepwave devices. For users with a single device who do not require remote access via the public internet, social logon, or site-to-site VPN, InControl2 may not be necessary. It is recommended to set up a user account on the InControl2 platform and register the device to secure ownership, after which InControl2 Management should be disabled on the device for enhanced security.

When adjusting bandwidth management values on a Pepwave device running firmware 3.5.2 build 1537, an error message indicates an 'Invalid Default Interim Interval' with an allowed range of 60 to 2678400 seconds. Additionally, the device's InControl status is offline, and users are encouraged to transition from InControl 1, which will eventually reach end-of-life (EOL), to the more powerful InControl2, available through a subscription model.
All variants of the AP Pro operate in standalone mode. InControl 2 support for these devices is expected to be available in approximately 2-3 months, although no exact time-frame has been provided.

In marine environments, Peplink routers facilitate reliable internet connectivity by utilizing multiple WAN connections, including satellite, cellular, and WiFi, to create a single onboard internet service. They support up to 13 different WAN links, allowing for the prioritization of lower-cost connections and intelligent management of bandwidth usage to minimize costs. Features include bandwidth monitoring, scheduled control of WAN usage, and the ability to cache frequently accessed content locally. Peplink devices can also manage multiple SIMs for cellular connectivity, enabling the use of local mobile networks instead of expensive roaming data. Additionally, SpeedFusion technology can provide secure, resilient VPN connections for real-time applications and corporate access, extending enterprise WAN capabilities to vessels.

For a livestreaming project using a cellular connection, a minimum upload bandwidth of approximately 2Mbps is required for a single HD video stream. If cellular coverage is good, a Peplink BR1 Slim can be used, which has a single cellular module with dual SIM slots for better coverage. If bandwidth is insufficient, cellular bonding is necessary, which requires a body-worn device and a cloud-based endpoint like FusionHub to manage the bonded traffic. The HD2 Mini is recommended for multi-cellular setups, supporting SpeedFusion bonding, while an AP One AC Mini can be added for WiFi. The MAX HD4 is a more advanced option with four cellular modules but may be overkill for this application. Antenna placement is also important for optimal signal, and using higher gain antennas or extension leads can help improve performance.

Peplink routers come with a one-year Hardware Warranty and one year of InControl 2 Access, which can be extended or added through TotalCare, Extended Warranty, or InControl 2 Subscription options. TotalCare is a premium service available for enterprise-grade models, offering hardware warranty, InControl 2 access, telephone support, 24x7 email support, and advance hardware replacement. The Extended Warranty is available for all models and includes hardware warranty and InControl 2 access. The InControl 2 Subscription provides access for one or two years but is limited to certain models.

The HD2-DOME is a router with an integrated LTE modem and antennas, not just an antenna. It provides an IP address via DHCP for the SIM Injector and other devices on the same LAN. The SIM Injector's PoE output can be enabled or disabled through its web management page, but the output voltage cannot be controlled. For installation details, the technical manual is available on the Peplink website, which includes various SIM Injector installation topology scenarios and optional settings for enabling roaming for SIM cards.

A proposed design for a mounting sleeve for the HD Dome includes an M35 Female thread on one end to cover the M35 thread of the Dome and a 1"x 14 standard Female thread on the other end to fit onto a 1"x 14 standard male maritime fitting. The material suggested for the mount is 316 stainless steel, and there is a consideration for a cable exit opening versus having cables go through the base. A design for a two-piece stainless mount has been created to prevent cable twisting during installation, although the manufacturing cost is noted to be high.

To bond multiple SIMs together in a Pepwave MAX-HD2 or MAX-HD4 for a single fast connection, a SpeedFusion Bonding license is required. However, the HD series devices come with the SpeedFusion Bonding license included. Product comparison pages provide information on which SpeedFusion features are supported natively and which require additional licensing or subscriptions.

To access a Peplink switch that is offline in INcontrol, it may be possible to use INTouch on the 20X router to connect to the LAN side IP of the switch. Additionally, changing the switch settings to auto for INcontrol instead of using a specific VLAN can help resolve connectivity issues with INcontrol.

A Peplink switch that is showing offline in INcontrol may still pass traffic, but if it cannot be accessed via the webGUI and has a red status light, it may indicate a hardware issue. In this case, the switch's fans were running at 100%, and after a power cycle, the Power over Ethernet (POE) functionality stopped working. The switch was subsequently RMA'd by support due to these issues.

To obtain a subscription for the MAX HD2 device, one should purchase EssentialCare instead of the InControl2 subscription, as Peplink does not sell IC2 subscriptions solely for the HD2. EssentialCare can be acquired through a Peplink partner.

To use InControl2 Management for Peplink devices, the device must have an active warranty or an InControl2 subscription. Users can register for an account at the InControl2 website to access its features. If the warranty or subscription expires, the device will show as offline in InControl2, but service will resume once the subscription or warranty is renewed.

To renew InControl2 or warranty for a SpeedFusion Engine CAM, it is recommended to submit a support ticket and provide the device's serial number. Essential Care is available for the SpeedFusion Engine CAM.

To restrict access from a remote Peplink modem to only allow connections to a specific cloud server's IP address, one can modify the default outbound firewall rule by setting it to Deny and Log. This configuration will block all outbound requests that do not match the specified IP address, while also logging any denied attempts for auditing purposes.

InControl 2 is included in the product warranty for the first year for various Peplink models. After the first year, it becomes optional. Velocity chip products and the MAX BR1 family have a purchasable InControl 2 license, while all Bluechip products (except for the MAX BR1 family) only offer an Extended Warranty license, which includes an InControl 2 extension. For pricing details, contacting a local certified Peplink partner is recommended.

When setting up InControl2 as a VM behind NAT, it is important to ensure that the Peplink router connects to the public DNS name of InControl rather than a private IP address. If the router is configured to connect to a non-public DNS name, it may result in connection timeouts for features like Remote Web Admin, despite TCP and UDP ports 5246 being forwarded correctly to the VM.

To continue using InControl2 after the warranty period for Peplink devices, users have two main options: maintain the warranty to access the Public Cloud or purchase and host their own Private InControl2 appliance. Alternatively, users can seek a regional partner that hosts a private InControl2 appliance and rent a subscription from them.
The footer stating "Powered by Peplink" in the Captive Portal login page cannot be removed or changed during customization.

To add users in InControl2, once a person is added, they will receive an email with a unique link. If the email is not received, the user can go to the InControl2 login page and select the 'Reset' option next to 'Forgot your password?' to receive a password reset email by entering their email address and clicking the Send button.

The false offline issue in InControl 2 (Earth) was resolved after approximately 8 hours, specifically at 10:00 GMT+0. However, currently about 40% of devices are unable to receive bulk configuration due to a known limitation, which is expected to be addressed in a future fix.

When the warranty for a Peplink device expires, the associated InControl 2 subscription also expires, causing the device to be deemed offline as it no longer reports to the InControl 2 cloud. To maintain access to InControl 2, a SmartCare license must be purchased to reactivate the warranty, which includes a new InControl 2 subscription. Alternatively, for some Peplink/Pepwave products, it is possible to purchase a standalone InControl 2 license at a lower cost than SmartCare.

To mass add devices for warranty extension and InControl access for a fleet of approximately 100 BR1s, Peplink partners can assist by ordering all licenses in one go if the serial numbers are provided. Users can choose to extend only the InControl 2 license or extend the warranty of the products, which includes the InControl 2 license.

InControl 2 is free for the first year and can remain free if extended warranty or SmartCare is purchased. After a device is out of warranty, a subscription fee of €29 for one year or €49 for two years per device is required to use InControl 2. Access to InControl 2 is available for various Peplink products, including Balance series, MAX BR series, Surf SOHO, and AP One series, provided they are under warranty. The Balance 380 can manage remote devices, and additional configuration information can be found in Peplink's knowledge base.

To integrate GPS maps from Peplink MAX BR1 routers into third-party applications, users can utilize the InControl API to extract GPS data. The relevant API documentation is available online, and the specific GET request for retrieving location data is /rest/o/{organization_id}/d/{device_id}/loc.
InControl2 MSP is compatible with VMware ESXi, allowing for installation on a VMware server. Further details can be found on the Peplink website.

Currently, InControl 2 (IC2) requires devices to be under warranty for management. If a device goes out of warranty, users must either renew the warranty or purchase an IC2 subscription to continue utilizing the management features. The subscription is considered affordable given the extensive capabilities that IC2 offers.

In FusionHub, inter-peer routing under NAT mode is not allowed. To enable inter-peer routing, NAT mode must be disabled. A pre-beta test feature is being developed to address this limitation, which may be available in the next two weeks.

Metal structures, such as the aluminum skin of a camper trailer, can attenuate radio frequency (RF) signals, leading to reduced Wi-Fi signal strength indoors compared to outdoors. To improve Wi-Fi reception when the BR1 Max Pro is inside the camper, it is recommended to use stick-style Wi-Fi antennas instead of relying on the roof-mounted antenna's leads.

Peplink devices can effectively bond multiple internet connections, including cellular and Starlink, using SpeedFusion technology. This solution has been successfully implemented for various companies and schools across the US and Canada, indicating its reliability in mobile settings. Additionally, there are custom cases available that incorporate patented antennas designed for optimal performance in streaming applications.

For exhibiting at events with multiple devices needing reliable internet, the B One 5G is recommended over the BR1 Mini 5G, as it can utilize a Peplink eSim for multi-carrier capability. The B One 5G can be managed locally without the need for Primecare, although opting out of Primecare results in losing features such as SpeedFusion, InControl, and InTouch. The effectiveness of the B One 5G with only the cellular connection active and client WiFi depends on the specific carrier and location.

The Max Transit Dual SIM model Max-tst-glte-g-t-prm includes a GPS antenna and is available for sale at $200 shipped. It is suitable for users looking for a device that supports dual SIM functionality and may require licenses for Fusion Solo and InControl2, along with optional Primecare or Essential Care support.

Managing DNS should ideally be retained by the organization rather than outsourced to a web hosting company, as it can lead to complications, especially when transitioning to a new provider. The claim that allowing the host to manage DNS will improve performance and security is questionable; performance enhancements are typically associated with dedicated services like Cloudflare, and security features can be independently implemented. Organizations should maintain control over their DNS records to avoid potential issues, such as being locked into a service or losing access to their domain. It is advisable to verify the domain registration details and ensure that the domain is owned by the organization to prevent complications in the future. Understanding DNS record types and their functions is crucial for effective management.

PTR records are associated with IP addresses rather than domains, and therefore no DNS provider, including Microsoft 365, supports the management of PTR records. To resolve issues with PTR lookups, one must contact the entity that issues the IP address, such as an ISP or hosting provider, to set the appropriate PTR record, as it cannot be modified through Microsoft 365.

The video discusses the concept of bonding and smoothing in network connections, highlighting that bonding uses the highest latency connection among multiple links, while smoothing can reduce latency by discarding higher latency packets. Smoothing is particularly beneficial for real-time applications like video calls and streaming, especially in variable network conditions. The discussion also covers the Peplink SpeedFusion technology, which enhances outbound policy management by allowing packet-level decisions and improving traffic shaping capabilities. The video demonstrates setting up VLANs for traffic isolation, configuring outbound policies, and managing connections to ensure reliable performance across different internet sources, including 5G and Starlink. Additionally, it addresses session persistence and the importance of managing traffic based on connection quality and type, including the use of SFC Protect for enhanced reliability.

InControl is a management platform for Peplink devices that provides a multi-tiered organizational structure, allowing users to manage devices at the organization, group, and device levels. Users can enable two-factor authentication, manage SIM cards, and create SIM pools for data utilization. The platform supports SpeedFusion configuration, which can be set at either the organization or group level, and allows for centralized firmware management across devices. Users can generate various reports, including device, Wi-Fi, and SIM card reports, and utilize features such as connection tests for performance monitoring. InControl also facilitates user management, including setting idle timeouts for compliance and customizing organization settings such as logos and addresses. Additionally, it provides warranty and license management, including the issuance of FusionHub licenses.

The SpeedFusion Connect Relay feature allows users to connect devices behind private IP addresses without requiring a public IP, enhancing connectivity for mobile applications like RVs. The latest firmware version 8.3 introduces Layer 3 connectivity for SpeedFusion Connect Relay, which improves the ability to bridge private networks. Additionally, users can now switch between SIM cards dynamically through the InControl interface, allowing for better management of cellular connections. Connection tests can be configured to monitor network performance, providing daily speed tests and reporting results in a graphical format. The SpeedFusion Connect app simplifies management of SpeedFusion services, enabling users to subscribe to LTE data, manage SIM cards, and set outbound policies easily, catering to both consumer and enterprise needs.

The video discusses the importance of maintaining an effective failover solution for internet connectivity, particularly in changing environments where performance may degrade over time. Peplink's SpeedFusion technology, including SpeedFusion Connect, allows users to manage their network infrastructure easily through an app, enabling features like LTE data subscription and SIM card management. The BR1 Pro 5G router can be integrated with the SpeedFusion Connect app, providing visibility and control over connected devices and enabling users to prioritize applications like Zoom. The app simplifies the process of purchasing data and managing connectivity without needing extensive technical knowledge. Additionally, the discussion touches on features like dynamic weighted bonding and TCP ramp-up, which enhance network performance and are accessible through Peplink's InControl management platform.

The video demonstrates how to configure wireless access management using InControl for Pepwave routers. Users can tag routers for group-based Wi-Fi settings, enabling centralized management. The process involves adding tags to routers, enabling Wi-Fi management, and creating a new SSID with WPA2 security settings. VLAN tagging, multicast filtering, and radio selection for both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands can also be configured. Once the settings are saved, the Wi-Fi configuration is pushed to the router via InControl, and any changes to the SSID must be made through InControl rather than locally on the router.

The video discusses the configuration of WAN connections and the use of SpeedFusion technology to manage internet traffic effectively. The use of WAN smoothing is highlighted, which enhances the performance of voice and video applications by bonding multiple internet connections. The video also covers the creation of outbound policies in InControl to prioritize traffic for specific applications like Zoom and Microsoft Teams, and the importance of selecting the right Peplink router based on user needs, such as the BR1 Pro 5G or HD4 MBX 5G, to optimize network performance. Additionally, it emphasizes the significance of application-based routing and traffic shaping in managing bandwidth effectively across different internet connections.

The video discusses the process of bulk updating firmware for multiple Pepwave routers using the actions menu in the dashboard. The process involves navigating to the dashboard, selecting the devices, and using the actions menu to push the desired firmware version, such as the HD1 Dome Pro 8.5 firmware, to all selected devices at once. This method eliminates the need for manual updates for each individual device, streamlining the firmware management process.

Peplink's bonding technology, particularly SpeedFusion, allows for the aggregation of multiple WAN connections, providing increased reliability and bandwidth without the need for specialized carrier connectivity. Unlike traditional IPsec and LACP bonding methods, which have limitations such as requiring identical circuits or being sensitive to latency and packet loss, SpeedFusion can utilize any internet connection from various providers, including 4G, 5G, DSL, and satellite. This dynamic bonding capability enables users to achieve higher throughput and reliability, making it a compelling solution for businesses needing consistent internet performance. The technology emerged from the need to bond multiple connections for applications requiring more bandwidth than a single connection could provide, demonstrating its effectiveness in real-world scenarios.

The video discusses the use of Peplink routers, specifically the BR2, to ensure reliable internet connectivity while traveling. It highlights the implementation of SpeedFusion technology to maximize reliability by combining multiple connections, including two Wi-Fi connections and cellular links. The speaker mentions using Synergy mode to combine two Peplink routers for increased bandwidth and the distinction between Synergy mode and Starlink mode, which allows the integration of Starlink modem capabilities into Peplink routers. The speaker also explains that any Peplink router with an Ethernet WAN port can support Starlink mode, provided it runs firmware version 8.4.1 or higher, and demonstrates the ability to reboot the Starlink dish remotely.

The video discusses two operational modes for Pepwave routers: relay mode, which allows the router to use a high-speed cable modem at home for internet access, and client mode for outbound connections. Peplink provides solutions for reliable internet connectivity by aggregating multiple connections, such as Starlink and cellular networks, to ensure seamless performance for real-time applications like Zoom and Teams. Peplink manages multiple WAN connections using outbound policies that allow for various algorithms, including round robin, to control traffic flow for all devices or specific ones. SpeedFusion is a proprietary VPN that utilizes multiple WANs to maintain continuous internet connectivity, aggregating bandwidth from different sources and providing failover capabilities. For instance, if one WAN fails, traffic seamlessly switches to another available WAN without interrupting ongoing sessions like Skype calls. The Max BR1 router has limitations with bonding two SIM cards due to its single modem architecture, but it can bond an active SIM card with Ethernet or Wi-Fi WANs using SpeedFusion. SpeedFusion technology enables seamless failover and bonding of multiple WAN connections, ensuring continuous internet connectivity. When one WAN connection fails, such as an Ethernet WAN, SpeedFusion automatically switches to cellular connections, maintaining traffic flow. Users can configure outbound policies to prioritize traffic through VPN links and can set up VLANs for VoIP traffic. The latest firmware version 8.1.0 introduces improved TCP acceleration for better performance over high-latency connections like VSAT. The Pepwave HD4 MBX supports multiple SpeedFusion tunnels and allows for advanced configurations, including bandwidth aggregation and failover rules. Throughput tests have shown capabilities of up to 360 Mbps using dual SIM cards, demonstrating effective load balancing across WAN connections.

The video discusses various connectivity solutions using Peplink routers, emphasizing the importance of maintaining internet connectivity through multiple modems and connections. Peplink routers offer several features that enhance connectivity and redundancy, particularly when paired with Starlink, which can experience dropouts due to obstructions. By using SpeedFusion bonding, users can combine Starlink with mobile hotspots or other WAN connections to mitigate these issues. Peplink's Synergy mode allows two routers to function as a single unit, providing an economical upgrade path for older models. Additionally, the relay mode enables a Peplink router at a home base to connect securely to a mobile router in a vehicle, allowing for seamless internet access as if from home. Peplink routers offer multiple internet connection options, allowing users to combine various sources such as cellular modems, Ethernet ports, and Wi-Fi for enhanced connectivity. Load balancing distributes traffic across available connections, while failover automatically switches to a backup connection if the primary fails. SpeedFusion is a proprietary SD-WAN technology that creates a VPN tunnel to combine multiple connections for improved reliability and performance. Additionally, WAN smoothing duplicates data across connections to ensure redundancy, although it consumes double the bandwidth. These features enable users to optimize their internet performance based on their specific needs and locations.

Pepwave's SpeedFusion technology allows the simultaneous use of two connections, such as cellular and Wi-Fi, by sending a VPN over both connections and combining their speeds and reliability into a single virtual connection. The Max Transit Duo router, priced at $999, supports dual CAT 12 connections and is designed for users needing redundancy and uninterrupted connectivity, allowing both modems to be active simultaneously without manual switching. The Peplink HD4 MBX 5G is a high-performance mobile router capable of providing reliable internet connectivity at events, achieving download speeds of up to 800 Mbps under optimal conditions and maintaining around 250 Mbps during peak congestion. Peplink offers a range of products suitable for mobile applications, including devices with one to 18 active cellular modems that can bond connections, spread traffic, and create session persistence. The SpeedFusion Hub can connect multiple customers and can be utilized for hot failover at a single site using a hosted VPN termination point in AWS. Peplink products are available with various power supply options to accommodate different geographic regions.

The Peplink B1 is a multi-WAN router designed for users with existing wired internet connections, such as T-Mobile home internet and Starlink. The B1 supports load balancing and can bond multiple Starlink connections using SpeedFusion technology for enhanced bandwidth and redundancy. The discussion centers around the comparison between a single 5G modem and dual 4G modems for mobile internet solutions. The video discusses the use of a multi-WAN router, specifically the Peplink Max Transit Pro, to achieve reliable mobile internet connectivity by combining multiple sources such as T-Mobile, Verizon, and Starlink. To utilize SpeedFusion or bonding, at least two Peplink devices are required, with one needing a public IP address. SpeedFusion Connect, Peplink's public bonding service, has a throughput limit of 200 Mbps, while hosting a FusionHub in a private cloud allows for unrestricted throughput based on the device's capabilities. WAN smoothing duplicates traffic across multiple connections to enhance reliability for VoIP and video applications, while Forward Error Correction (FEC) minimizes overhead during one-way communications. The video discusses the technical aspects of bonding multiple internet connections, particularly in the context of using Peplink's SpeedFusion technology. It highlights the importance of understanding latency when bonding connections, as the overall latency of a bonded connection is determined by the slowest link. For example, bonding a high-latency VSAT connection with lower-latency LTE connections will result in the bonded connection operating at the higher latency. The use of WAN smoothing is recommended to mitigate latency spikes and packet loss, especially for voice and video applications. The video also emphasizes the significance of load balancing between connections, such as Starlink and 5G, where Starlink's TCP optimization may perform better when not bonded for certain applications like Netflix. Additionally, it mentions the overhead associated with SpeedFusion compared to traditional IP tunneling, noting that SpeedFusion incurs approximately 18% overhead. Factors affecting WAN performance, such as signal strength and backhaul availability, are also discussed, indicating that multiple connections may not increase throughput if the tower's capacity is limited. Lastly, the importance of having active SIM cards and suitable data plans is highlighted as a common issue affecting connectivity.

The Peplink ecosystem integrates multiple internet sources, including fiber, broadband, 5G, LTE, and satellite, into a unified hardware and software platform to enhance connectivity reliability and speed. The HD4 MBX router is highlighted for its capability to combine various internet connections, providing a robust solution for enterprise, maritime, and mission-critical applications. The system supports SpeedFusion technology, which allows for seamless bonding of connections to ensure stable internet access, even in challenging environments. Some Peplink devices, such as the Balance 310-5G and BR1 Pro 5G, support 5G in Standalone (SA) mode, but this may require a special firmware build obtained through a support ticket. The availability of SA bands in the Band Selection dropdown menu may vary by model and firmware version.

Carrier aggregation (CA) performance can vary based on the carrier's implementation rather than the limitations of the Peplink hardware or Sierra Wireless modem. In the USA, major carriers like Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile manage CA differently, which can affect the number of bands utilized. The user has observed that while they can achieve up to 5 band CA initially, it tends to drop to 2 bands after about an hour, impacting speeds. The user has not experienced CA dropping below 2 bands, and the response suggests that the carrier's management of CA may be influenced by network conditions and usage patterns.

The Peplink MAX BR1 5G Pro supports band 14, which is used by FirstNet, suggesting potential compatibility with the network. However, it is not explicitly listed on the FirstNet page, so confirmation from Peplink support may be necessary for definitive compatibility information.

The Peplink Max HD2 Dome does not support 5G, making the Peplink MBX Mini a better choice for 4/5G connectivity. The performance of cellular connections depends significantly on the location, capacity, and configuration of cell towers. A multi-modem router increases the likelihood of maintaining service by allowing the use of multiple carriers. For optimal performance, antenna cable lengths should be kept short (ideally under 5m/15ft) to minimize signal loss. Load balancing is available out of the box without additional service plans, but for bonding or hitless failover, SpeedFusion is required, which incurs costs depending on the chosen service plan. Using SpeedFusion Cloud or hosting a FusionHub can provide additional features, including inbound routing for remote access to devices on the boat.

For a sailing boat installation of multi modem LTE, it is suggested to consider Maritime antennas over Mobility antennas for improved performance, especially in varying sea conditions. While the Peplink MBX Mini with 2x Mobility 40G offers 4x4 MIMO and higher effective gain, the use of specialized Maritime antennas could provide significant advantages in terms of connectivity and reliability. The impact of antenna choice on expected bandwidth near shore and range should be evaluated, particularly for maintaining a minimum of 500 kbit/s for applications like WhatsApp calls and basic surfing/email. When considering antenna placement, it's important to engage with a local partner experienced in marine setups due to the unique challenges posed by the maritime environment. For a boat setup requiring multiple cellular connections, it is feasible to use two Pepwave MAX Transit Duo units, each with two different cellular connections, to potentially bond up to four active links. For achieving cellular connectivity on a boat, it is suggested to consider using WiFi as WAN at marinas instead of relying solely on cellular connections, as cellular service can be unreliable offshore. query: Why might a SpeedFusion tunnel with two LTE connections deliver slower speeds than the fastest individual link, and what steps can be taken to optimize throughput, based on real-world deployments and troubleshooting examples?
answer: A SpeedFusion tunnel using two LTE connections can deliver slower speeds than the fastest individual link because bonded throughput is often limited by the slowest or most latent connection, resulting in average or lower-than-expected speeds rather than a simple sum. This occurs due to the way SpeedFusion handles packet distribution, overhead, and the need to manage differing latencies and packet loss across links. Real-world deployments show that if one LTE link is degraded (e.g., higher latency, packet loss, or lower bandwidth), it can drag down the overall tunnel performance. To optimize throughput, several steps should be taken: (1) ensure both LTE connections have good signal quality and minimal interference, (2) use high-quality, properly positioned antennas to reduce cross-talk and maximize signal, (3) adjust SpeedFusion settings such as latency cutoff and dynamic weighted bonding to favor the better-performing link, (4) update to the latest firmware to benefit from recent improvements in bonding algorithms, (5) avoid including high-latency or unstable links in the bond, and (6) test with different protocol modes (such as experimental TCP) to identify the mode that best suits the connection characteristics. Monitoring WAN statistics, packet loss, latency, and firmware version is essential to fine-tune the configuration and achieve the best possible performance.

citations.claim: SpeedFusion tunnels with two LTE connections can be slower than the fastest link, resulting in average speeds rather than the sum due to how bonding works and the impact of latency and packet loss.
If one LTE connection is degraded, it can negatively impact the tunnel's overall performance, dragging down speeds and causing packet loss or high latency.
Proper antenna setup, including using quality external antennas and placing them to reduce cross-talk, can improve LTE signal quality and optimize bonding performance.
Adjusting SpeedFusion settings, such as latency cutoff and enabling dynamic weighted bonding, can help favor the better-performing link and improve throughput.
Updating to the latest firmware (e.g., 8.1.0 RC1 or RC2) can enhance bonding performance due to improvements in dynamic weighted bonding and bonding algorithms.
Testing with experimental protocol modes (like TCP) can sometimes yield better performance than the standard mode, depending on the characteristics of the LTE links.
Monitoring WAN statistics, packet loss, latency, and firmware version is important for diagnosing and optimizing SpeedFusion performance.
Avoiding the inclusion of high-latency or unstable links in the bond can prevent them from dragging down the overall bonded speed.
