These rules could block the management sessions necessary for the device to connect to InControl2. It is advisable to check for such rules and ensure that the device can ping incontrol2.peplink.com to verify connectivity.

The USSD feature on the Pepwave Max BR1 was broken in firmware version 6.3.3 build 2252, as USSD codes enclosed in hashtags (like #123#) return an 'invalid USSD code' error, while they function correctly in firmware version 6.3.1 build 2023. Users are advised to revert to version 6.3.1 for proper functionality until the issue is resolved. There is no confirmation regarding the functionality of hashtag symbols in USSD codes with version 7 firmware, and users should be cautious about upgrading without this information.
For the MAX HD2 LTE IP67, the power connector part number is ACW-636. Additionally, the PoE injector for this device has a different part number, which is ACW-107.

For a stable internet connection in South Korea for P2P live videostreaming, it is recommended to use a Pepwave MAX-HD2-Mini-LTE-E-T, MAX-HD2-LTE-E-T, or MAX-HD4-LTE-E-T, as the MAX-On-The-Go and MAX-BR1-LTE-E-T do not support bandwidth bonding. Utilizing Peplink's SpeedFusion VPN with the existing Balance 310 can significantly improve the chances of achieving the required stable speed of 12 MBits for several hours of transmission.
The default IP address for configuring the Pepwave MAX BR1 router is 192.168.50.1. To access the configuration page wirelessly, one must connect to the built-in access point (AP) of the BR1.

For streaming live events in 720p, the Pepwave MAX-HD4-LTE is recommended as it comes with 4 embedded LTE/3G modems. Utilizing SpeedFusion VPN bonding technology allows for the combination of multiple connections, maximizing upload speed and providing redundancy in case one carrier drops off. This setup can help achieve the required upload speed of 3 to 4.5 Mbps for streaming.

To configure a WAN port as a LAN port on a Pepwave MAX BR1 Slim, it is important to ensure that the router management via InControl2 (IC2) is temporarily disabled, as it may overwrite local settings. Additionally, the power source should be capable of providing 2A of current to ensure proper functionality of the router during configuration changes.

To insert a SIM card into the Max BR1 LTE, it should be oriented with the gold contacts facing down and the notched side going in first. The SIM card will click into place when inserted correctly. To eject the SIM card, push it inward until it clicks out.
The MAX BR1 router has a maximum throughput capability of 100Mbps. The MAX-BR1-LTE-E-T model does not support CAT.3 LTE speed; instead, CAT.3 LTE is supported by the MAX-BR1-LTE-T model.

For configuring multiple Pepwave Max BR1 devices, the InControl2 cloud management platform can be used to store configurations in the cloud and push them to all devices, facilitating pre-staging of configurations.

To enable two-factor authentication for users in InControl, one should navigate to organization settings and select the options for two-factor authentication and to force users to set it up. The term 'users' refers specifically to users of InControl and not to Wi-Fi AP clients.

To schedule a regular reboot for a Pepwave Surf SOHO, users can do so via InControl by navigating to Settings -> Device System Management and enabling the 'Scheduled Reboot - Managed' option, allowing for daily or weekly scheduling. Alternatively, users can access the device's LAN IP address, modify the URL to include 'support.cgi', and find the option to schedule a daily or weekly reboot on that page.
The Peplink UBR LTE is currently not available in a 5G variant, as confirmed by the datasheet provided by Peplink.

When using inControl2 to manage AP One minis connected to a Peplink Balance 20X, the APs will show as offline on the Balance 20X since inControl2 takes over management. Users must recreate their settings in inControl2 or configure them locally on the APs to retain previous configurations, as there is no straightforward way to import existing settings into inControl2.

Cellular-enabled Peplink and Pepwave products utilize the Mini-SIM (2FF) form factor. If a SIM card is smaller than this size, it can be adapted using a SIM card adapter. An alternative to using an adapter is to purchase a prepaid SIM card that comes with various punch-out sizes, allowing users to select the appropriate size for their device.

Cellular-enabled Peplink and Pepwave products typically use the Mini-SIM (2FF) form factor, but the current Max Transit Duo LTEA model uses the full-size SIM card (1FF). If a SIM card is smaller than the required size, a SIM card adapter can be used to increase its size.

Cellular-enabled Peplink and Pepwave products primarily use the Mini-SIM (2FF) form factor for SIM cards. In cases where a smaller SIM card is used, a SIM card adapter can be utilized to increase the size. The SpeedFusion Engine (SFE) specifically requires two Micro-SIMs (3FF), one for each modem.

The SIM Injector can power up from a 12V source, but it will not provide Power over Ethernet (PoE) output at that voltage. For PoE functionality, it is recommended to connect the SIM Injector to a power source between 48-56V, with 56V being the preferred option for optimal performance.

By default, there is no VPN enabled on a Peplink router. To troubleshoot issues with VPN access when using a Pepwave Max BRQ mini, it is suggested to reset the router, connect a laptop to the LAN port, log into the router, enter the SIM card PIN, and insert the SIM card.

The T-Mobile Home Internet (TMHI) SIM card is likely locked to the IMEI of the Nokia 5G21 gateway, which means it may not work in a Pepwave MAX BR1 Pro 5G. TMHI is reported to be stricter than other plans, and while some users have managed to use TMHI SIMs in different devices by changing the IMEI, this may not be feasible with Pepwave devices.

The Pepwave Max BR1 Pro 5G can be activated on T-Mobile's business internet plans, which require a business Tax ID for activation. T-Mobile's service policy applies to all certified devices, including Peplink's TMO-certified devices. Additionally, Peplink devices are compatible with T-Mobile's consumer hotspot/data/router plans, subject to T-Mobile's terms and conditions.

To resolve issues with a MAX Transit Cat 18 modem that is stuck on obtaining an IP address despite having a strong signal, it is crucial to verify that the Access Point Name (APN) assigned by AT&T is exactly correct, as this can affect connectivity.

To troubleshoot an issue where a device is unable to obtain an IP address from T-Mobile, it is suggested to check if the SIM card works in a cell phone, verify if an APN or SIM PIN is required, and consider that some plans may block connections based on the router's IMEI. Additionally, setting an APN if needed, relocating the device away from Wi-Fi or RF devices, and positioning the antennas in a V format may help improve connectivity. If these steps do not resolve the issue and an APN is not required, it is possible that the provider is blocking the connection.

The IMEI number for a Pepwave device can be found on the dashboard by clicking the details button next to the cellular field. Additionally, it is also visible in IC2 by selecting details for the Cell module under the list of WANs, specifically noted for the Peplink Balance 20X running firmware version 8.1.1.

For users considering an LTE modem, the Max BR1 Mini with the LTE-A (Cat 6) radio is recommended over the standard LTE version due to its potential for faster speeds, especially in areas with upgraded LTE spectrum. Users have reported speeds of 30-35 Mbps during non-peak hours and 10-20 Mbps during peak hours, indicating variability based on network congestion. The additional cost of the LTE-A version may be justified by the improved performance.
The Cricket unlimited plan is compatible with Pepwave Max Transit devices and has been reported to work as intended by users.

To resolve the issue of a Max BR1 router getting stuck at obtaining an IP address with an AT&T card, it is important to ensure that the SIM card is a data-only card suitable for use in hotspots. If the card works in a phone but not in the router, it may indicate that the wrong card type is being used, as the provisioning of the card is crucial for compatibility with the device.
The Pepwave MAX Transit Mini is now certified for use on the Verizon network, indicating compatibility with Verizon SIM cards for authentication.
The InControl 2 API does not support Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS) and only supports requests made from server-side applications.

To create new accounts in InControl, a working email address is typically required, but there is a workaround to activate accounts without email verification by resetting the password through the MSP > Search page. It is recommended to create a personal MSP admin account and remove the default admin@my.domain account for better account management.

In Peplink's InControl2 fleet management system, a green icon indicates that the device has a backdated fleet management report. A dotted line on the map signifies that the device was losing GPS signal.

To reset the login details for a Pepwave MAX-HD2-MINI-LTE-E configured with IC2, one should log in using the existing Super Administrative Login, create a new Super Administrative Login at the organizational level, log out of the old account, and then log in with the new account. If these steps do not resolve the issue, raising a support ticket is recommended.
The footer stating "Powered by Peplink" in the Captive Portal login page cannot be removed or changed during customization.

To add users in InControl2, once a person is added, they will receive an email with a unique link. If the email is not received, the user can go to the InControl2 login page and select the 'Reset' option next to 'Forgot your password?' to receive a password reset email by entering their email address and clicking the Send button.

To set up email notifications for WAN connection status on a Peplink Balance, users can navigate to Group > Settings > Notifications to create multiple notification profiles for various purposes. This allows for more reliable notification management compared to using the CE device for sending alerts.

To unregister a router from an InControl2 account, one should remove the device from its current group within the existing organization. After this, the router can be added to a new organization or account.

To move a device from one group to another within InControl, navigate to the Group Dashboard page, click on Manage, select the device by ticking the corresponding box, and then use the Actions pull-down menu to select Move.

Currently, InControl 2 (IC2) requires devices to be under warranty for management. If a device goes out of warranty, users must either renew the warranty or purchase an IC2 subscription to continue utilizing the management features. The subscription is considered affordable given the extensive capabilities that IC2 offers.

Metal structures, such as the aluminum skin of a camper trailer, can attenuate radio frequency (RF) signals, leading to reduced Wi-Fi signal strength indoors compared to outdoors. To improve Wi-Fi reception when the BR1 Max Pro is inside the camper, it is recommended to use stick-style Wi-Fi antennas instead of relying on the roof-mounted antenna's leads.
To configure two VLAN WANs on a Pepwave BR1 Pro, a license purchase is required to enable this functionality.

When using a preowned BR1 Max Pro LTEA, it is important to ensure that any antennas used are compatible with the router's frequencies. Additionally, for a preowned router, it is necessary to check that it has been released from the previous InControl account. Creating a new InControl2 account and adding the device's serial number is required; if the device is still associated with another organization, the previous owner must release it to allow full control over the router's settings and management.

To set up a Pepwave BR1 Max Mini 5G for an event using hotel WAN as the primary connection and a SIM card as failover, ensure that the device is connected to an InControl2 account for management. In the router's admin interface, set the WAN connection to priority 1 and the cellular connection to priority 2 to configure the failover correctly.

Peplink devices support OpenVPN server functionality, which can be used to establish a VPN tunnel. To connect from uncontrolled networks, it is recommended to utilize SpeedFusion Relay or another Peplink device on a controlled network, which can connect through FusionHub to create a VPN. If a FusionHub is available, direct connection is possible. For accessing services over protocols like SSH, Telnet, VNC, RDP, or HTTPS, InControl2 with InTouch can be used for easier management and access.

To troubleshoot a Pepwave MAX Transit Cat 18 modem that is stuck at 'Obtaining IP Address' while using a T-Mobile data plan, it is suggested to check the Access Point Name (APN) settings. One should compare the APN used by the working Cat 12 unit and set the same APN as a custom one in the new Cat 18 unit to resolve the connectivity issue.

When setting up a T-Mobile SIM card in a Pepwave BR1 Mini, if it is stuck on obtaining an IP address, it may be due to the SIM card being limited to certain IMEI numbers. To resolve this, it is recommended to first insert the SIM card into a phone, complete the activation process, ensure it receives a phone number, and use data for a few minutes before reinserting it into the Pepwave device.

To enable GPS forwarding on a Peplink router, access the advanced menu and select miscellaneous settings, then click on GPS forwarding. Check the enable box to expand the menu, and input the destination IP address or hostname along with a port number, which can be any number that the server accepts. Choose between UDP or TCP, with UDP being the default. The reporting interval can be set to one second or adjusted to a longer interval, such as five seconds for stationary reporting. Optionally, a vehicle ID can be added to modify the reporting format. After configuring the settings, click Save and then apply changes. The GPS data will begin streaming to the specified destination once the changes are applied.

Upgrading the firmware on a Peplink or Pepwave router can be performed through the web administration page or InControl 2. To upgrade via the web interface, users must connect to the router either through Ethernet or Wi-Fi, log into the administration page, and check the current firmware version. For manual upgrades, users need to download the appropriate firmware from the Peplink website after confirming their router's hardware revision. The manual upgrade process involves selecting the downloaded firmware file and initiating the upgrade, during which a backup of the current configuration settings is recommended. Users should refrain from using the router during the upgrade process, as it will temporarily disconnect Wi-Fi users and power down around 90% completion. After the upgrade, users must change the default admin password before accessing the router with the new firmware version.

The video demonstrates how to set up a Wireless Distribution System (WDS) and a mesh network using Peplink's AP series access points. WDS is used to extend wireless network coverage without Ethernet cables, beneficial for businesses and institutions. Peplink's AP devices allow for enterprise-grade Wi-Fi with customizable captive portals and centralized management via InControl2. The mesh network offers a more dynamic solution, enabling all access points to communicate in a star topology, enhancing reliability by providing alternative paths if one node fails. The setup process involves configuring the root AP and additional APs through their web admin pages, including settings for WDS and mesh networks, monitoring network status, signal strength, and event logs. DHCP can be used to verify client connections to the WDS.

The Pepwave BR1 Mini Core is certified for Verizon and is a category 4 modem designed for installations where constant connectivity is not required. It does not support USB tethering, which is available on higher category modems like the MBX. The Max Transit series lacks USB ports for tethering, and users seeking this feature should consider alternative models. In high-density environments, the 5 GHz Wi-Fi may frequently fall back to 2.4 GHz, which can take two to three minutes; users experiencing issues are encouraged to open a support ticket. For bandwidth management, limits can be set per interface, and for high latency connections like satellite, it is recommended to use them as failover connections rather than bonding them with other connections due to latency differences.

The Pepwave lineup includes several models tailored for different user needs, such as the Max BR1 Mini (Category 7), Max Transit Duo (with Category 7 and Category 12 modems), Max BR1 Pro (Category 20), and Max BR1 Pro 5G. The theoretical speeds for these models range from 300 Mbps download and 150 Mbps upload for the BR1 Mini to 4 Gbps download and 700 Mbps upload for the 5G model. Carrier aggregation capabilities allow these units to connect to multiple cellular bands simultaneously, enhancing performance. All models support dual-band Wi-Fi, with the BR1 Mini requiring a failover license for Wi-Fi WAN functionality. The BR1 Mini uses Wi-Fi 5 technology, while the other models utilize Wi-Fi 6, which offers improved performance in congested areas. Pepwave devices employ military-grade encryption for secure data transmission and come with all necessary accessories for setup, including a power supply and antennas. They utilize nano SIM cards and support various carriers, including T-Mobile's band 71.

The Max BR1 Pro 5G and Max BR1 Pro Cat 20 LTE models from Pepwave share the same form factor, with the 5G model being backwards compatible with 4G LTE, while the Cat 20 model is limited to 4G LTE. Both units are compatible with major cellular carriers and support updated bands, including band 71. They offer a theoretical throughput of 1 Gbps, with the Cat 20 capable of 2 Gbps download and 150 Mbps upload, and the 5G model capable of 2 Gbps download and 700 Mbps upload. Both models feature five times carrier aggregation for downloads and three times for uploads, enhancing performance by connecting to multiple bands simultaneously. They support dual-band Wi-Fi (2.4 GHz and 5 GHz) and utilize Wi-Fi 6 technology for improved speed and range. MIMO technology is employed for better data transmission, and military-grade encryption is used for secure data transmission, ensuring high security for sensitive information.

Pepwave utilizes VPN technology to ensure secure data transmission by encrypting data into small pieces with military-grade encryption, making it nearly impossible for unauthorized access. The Pepwave unit includes two Wi-Fi antennas, four cellular antennas, and a GPS receiver, with a 4-pin Molex connection for power. It features two LAN ports and a WAN port that can be assigned as a LAN port if needed. The device supports two nano SIM cards for cellular connectivity, allowing users to manage multiple data plans. The unit is compatible with external antennas for improved performance and comes with a one-year warranty and access to the InControl2 platform for remote management. Additionally, it offers SpeedFusion services for enhanced connectivity, including hot failover and WAN smoothing, which are crucial for users requiring reliable internet for activities like video conferencing.

The video provides a step-by-step guide for installing special firmware on Peplink devices to enable compatibility with Verizon's C-band for 5G business internet. The first step involves updating the cellular module firmware by confirming an active internet connection, selecting the devices to upgrade, and executing the update action, which takes 5 to 20 minutes. The second step requires upgrading the device firmware with a custom firmware URL, which can be obtained from a linked blog post. Users must paste the URL into the firmware URL field, verify it, select an immediate update time, and save changes to complete the process, making the device ready for Verizon's C-band and 5G services.

The video provides a tutorial on upgrading the firmware of a Peplink router using two methods: the web GUI and a manual upgrade. To upgrade via the web GUI, users must ensure the router has an active internet connection, navigate to the system settings, check for firmware updates, and download the active configuration before initiating the upgrade. For a manual upgrade, users need to identify the router model and hardware revision, download the appropriate firmware from the Peplink website, and then upload it through the web GUI. In both methods, it is crucial to avoid interrupting the upgrade process and to keep the router powered on until the upgrade is complete.

To update the firmware on a Max BR1 Mini, access the web GUI by entering the device's IP address (192.168.50.1) and logging in with the default username and password (admin/admin). Check the current firmware version under the status tab; if it is 7.1.1, you must first upgrade to 7.1.2 before proceeding to 8.0. Download the necessary firmware files from the Peplink support site, ensuring to check the firmware archive for intermediate versions. Perform the upgrade by dragging the firmware file into the manual upgrade section of the web GUI. The upgrade process takes up to six minutes, indicated by the status light changing from red to green. After upgrading to 7.1.2, repeat the process to upgrade to 8.0, confirming the successful upgrade by checking the status page again. These steps apply to any Peplink or Pepwave device.

The Pepwave Max BR1 Pro 5G is a redesigned modem featuring a category 20 5G modem and a 2.5 gigabit WAN port that can be assigned as a LAN port. It includes four cellular antennas and two Wi-Fi 6 antennas supporting both 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz frequencies. The modem has a maximum throughput of 1 gigabit and supports speeds of up to 400 megabits for unencrypted SpeedFusion tunnels. It utilizes nano SIM cards and features an ignition sense port for vehicle applications. The modem also supports Wi-Fi WAN bonding and comes with a power adapter that uses a micro molex connector, moving away from the previous barrel connector design. Additionally, it includes GPS capabilities and wire management accessories to enhance installation.

Updating the firmware on Pepwave devices is a straightforward process that can resolve various issues. To initiate an update, log in to the admin console, navigate to the 'System' tab, and select 'Firmware'. Users can check for the latest firmware version, which requires an internet connection to download and install. It is crucial to keep the device powered during the update to avoid potential damage. After the update, users may need to change their admin password, and they can verify the firmware version in the same section. If problems arise with the new firmware, there is an option to revert to the previous version by selecting it in the reboot settings, allowing users to troubleshoot effectively while maintaining functionality.

The Peplink MAX BR1 Mini (HW3) has a WAN port rated at 1 Gbps, but its actual throughput capacity is limited to 300 Mbps, which is a common characteristic in many networking products. This means that even when connected to a higher-speed internet connection, the router may not be able to utilize the full bandwidth due to its inherent throughput limitations.

The Peplink MAX BR1 Mini (HW3) has a rated throughput of 300 Mbps, which applies even when connected to the internet through its 1 Gbps WAN port. Users have observed that the maximum throughput when using this router can reach 250-300 Mbps, indicating a potential limit on the WAN port's performance, especially when compared to other routers like the Unifi EdgeRouter POE-5 that can achieve higher speeds with the same internet connection.

The rated throughput of the Peplink MAX BR1 Mini (HW3) is 300 Mbps, which applies to its overall router capacity rather than the WAN port capacity, which is 1 Gbps. Users can expect actual TCP throughput to be around 270 Mbps based on general experiences with Peplink routers. This means that while the WAN port can handle connections up to 1 Gbps, the router's throughput limit caps the effective speed to approximately 300 Mbps.

When experiencing significantly lower download speeds compared to upload speeds on a Max BR1 Mini with a Verizon LTE SIM, it may be due to a busy cell tower, which often has more congestion on the download path. The signal levels indicate good RSSI but lower RSRP, suggesting that the tower's load affects download performance. To potentially improve download speeds, it is recommended to conduct speed tests during off-peak hours, such as early morning or overnight, to see if bandwidth improves when the tower is less congested.

Different models from the BR1 mini Series are available, which support various cellular bands. To troubleshoot connectivity issues with deployed units in Mexico, it is important to check the specific bands supported by the modems and compare them with the bands used by the local cellular network. Additionally, reviewing the Dashboard for error messages or connection status can provide insights into the problem.

Carrier aggregation (CA) performance can vary based on the carrier's implementation rather than the limitations of the Peplink hardware or Sierra Wireless modem. In the USA, major carriers like Verizon, AT&T, and T-Mobile manage CA differently, which can affect the number of bands utilized. The user has observed that while they can achieve up to 5 band CA initially, it tends to drop to 2 bands after about an hour, impacting speeds. The user has not experienced CA dropping below 2 bands, and the response suggests that the carrier's management of CA may be influenced by network conditions and usage patterns.

To regain access to a Soho mk3 router after losing the username and password, users can utilize the Remote Web Admin feature through the InControl2 central management platform. If InControl2 is not available, a factory reset is necessary, which will erase all current configurations on the router.
To reset the username and password for a Soho mk3 router without losing the current configuration, access the device dashboard in InControl2 and navigate to the settings for remote web admin.

To ensure that the Pepwave MAX BR1 LTE US T is up to date, users should log in to the device and check the hardware version on the status page. They can then visit the Peplink support downloads page to find the appropriate firmware version for their model. For example, the MAX BR1 with HW2-3 uses firmware version 8.0.2, while HW1 uses version 6.3.5, with specific download links provided for each version.
To configure guest accounts on InControl for a Pepwave Balance 20, 802.1q VLAN support is required, which is supported by all Balance routers. The Balance 20 can support a maximum of 16 802.1q VLANs.

For site-to-site VPN configurations involving Peplink devices, using SpeedFusion VPN is recommended over traditional IPSec due to its ability to maintain VPN connections during WAN failures and to aggregate bandwidth from multiple WAN connections. SpeedFusion provides military-grade 256-bit AES encryption for data security and is noted for its ease of setup. The conversation also highlights issues with double NAT and private IP addresses in the context of VPN configurations, particularly with Cisco ASA and Peplink devices.

To establish a site-to-site VPN between a Peplink-360 and Peplink-310 with a Cisco ASA, it is important to address the double NAT issue and the private IP configuration on the ASA. The peer ID on the Branch Peplink-310 should match the WAN IP of the HQ Peplink-360. The Branch Peplink-310 can operate with a PPPoE dialer and a fixed IP, but it is crucial to determine if aggressive mode is necessary for both the Peplink and Cisco ASA configurations. Creating a SpeedFusion VPN profile between the Peplink devices allows for custom outbound rules to manage traffic across the tunnel effectively.

In a network topology where a Cisco ASA is behind a Peplink-360 configured in VPN passthrough mode, issues arise due to double NAT and the use of a private IP address on the ASA. The peer ID on the Branch Peplink-310 is incorrectly identified as the private IP of the Cisco ASA instead of the WAN IP of the HQ Peplink-360. The Branch Peplink-310 has a PPPoE dialer with a fixed IP, which raises questions about its classification as a static IP and its compatibility with aggressive mode. The configuration attempts included using main mode for IKE1 and switching to aggressive mode, but success has not been achieved. The conversation also raises the need to consider whether the Cisco ASA should be configured in aggressive mode or main mode, and whether any adjustments are necessary on the HQ Peplink-360 in passthrough mode.

In a network setup involving a Peplink-360 and Cisco ASA, the Peplink-360 is configured in VPN passthrough mode, which allows VPN traffic to pass through to the Cisco ASA. The Cisco ASA has a private IP address on its outside interface, leading to a double NAT situation. The Branch Peplink-310 is using a PPPoE dialer with a fixed IP address. For VPN configuration, the peer ID on the Branch Peplink-310 is incorrectly showing the private IP of the Cisco ASA instead of the WAN IP of the HQ Peplink-360. To resolve this, it is suggested to configure the Cisco ASA to use its private LAN IP as its WAN IP and set the Peplink as its WAN Gateway, avoiding the need to reconfigure remote VPN endpoints. Alternatively, obtaining a new WAN IP range for drop-in mode could be considered, but this would require significant reconfiguration.

To activate a SIM card for a BR1 MAX MK2, the IMEI number can be found on the box rather than the device itself. If the admin password is not recognized after changing it, one option is to reset the router using a paperclip, which will allow logging back in. Alternatively, connecting a wired WAN cable and adding the device to InControl2 can bring it online.

To successfully configure DNS-O-Matic with a Peplink gateway running firmware 5.4, users should enter **all.dnsomatic.com** as the host value in the Peplink UI. This allows the Peplink device to communicate with DNS-O-Matic, which will then update all configured services, including OpenDNS. This solution addresses the requirement for a host value in the Peplink firmware while ensuring proper functionality with DNS-O-Matic's API.

To configure DNS-O-Matic with a Peplink gateway, it is suggested to have one DNS-O-Matic account for each WAN connection. For example, Peplink WAN1 can be set to use DNS-O-Matic for OpenDNS and DynDNS, while Peplink WAN2 can similarly use a separate DNS-O-Matic account for its respective services. The specific DNS addresses for OpenDNS should be set as opendns1.dnsomatic.com for WAN1 and opendns2.dnsomatic.com for WAN2.

DNS-O-Matic is primarily designed for redundancy in dynamic DNS services within a single-WAN environment, which may lead to complications when attempting to use it with a multi-WAN setup on a Peplink Balance 20. The required 'Hosts' field in the Peplink UI may not align with DNS-O-Matic's functionality, as DNS-O-Matic does not necessarily require a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN) for all its supported services, such as OpenDNS. This mismatch could result in the Peplink device not successfully communicating with DNS-O-Matic, as indicated by the account not receiving updates from the Balance 20.

To configure DNS-O-Matic on Pepwave routers, users must enter their username and password in the Dynamic DNS Settings. The 'Hosts' field is required, and users can either check 'Update All Hosts' or specify a host like 'all.dnsomatic.com'. However, updates may fail if the router's implementation does not comply with DNS-O-Matic's evolving API requirements. The API documentation specifies that clients must send a well-formed User-Agent string that includes the company name, model number, and software build revision to avoid failed update requests. Event log entries can provide insights into update failures, indicating internal errors during the update process.

To configure DNS-O-Matic on a Peplink gateway, the 'Hosts' field in the UI requires a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN), which may not align with DNS-O-Matic's functionality of sending IP address updates to various services. Users have reported issues with DNS-O-Matic updates being broken since July, but direct updates via the DNS-O-Matic URL with the same login credentials successfully update the service.

To set up DNS-O-Matic on a Peplink Balance router, the 'Hosts' field in the UI requires a Fully Qualified Domain Name (FQDN), which may not align with how DNS-O-Matic operates, as it sends IP address updates to various services without needing a specific host. Users have reported issues with authentication errors when attempting to update DNS-O-Matic from their Peplink devices, while the same credentials work on other devices like a Synology NAS.

To set up DNS-O-Matic with a Peplink Balance 20 gateway, users need to fill in their email and password information in the updated UI. However, the 'Hosts' field is required and may cause confusion since DNS-O-Matic does not exclusively deal with hosts but sends IP address updates to various services. Users have reported issues with the Peplink device not being recognized by DNS-O-Matic, which may indicate a mismatch in the data being sent. For troubleshooting, users are advised to refer to external support resources and consider using the Find My Peplink service as an alternative.

To log into the Peplink router admin interface after changing the security to HTTPS, the default address to access is https://192.168.1.1 for Balance series routers, unless the port or address has been changed. This address can typically be found on the label on the bottom of the device.

When attempting to log into the Peplink router admin interface, if a 'server stopped responding' error occurs while internet access remains functional, it may be related to changes made to the security settings, such as switching to HTTPS. To access the web admin interface, the default IP address of the router, typically '192.168.50.1', should be used in the browser's address bar. If this does not resolve the issue, further investigation into the web admin port settings may be necessary.

Once the warranty of an access point (AP) managed by IC2 expires, new configurations cannot be pushed to the device from IC2. However, the expiration of the warranty does not impact the configurations that have already been applied to the device.

To successfully reset the admin password on a router, the new password should be entered in the 'Shared Key' field, followed by saving and applying the changes. The password can consist of up to 63 ASCII or extended ASCII characters. Additionally, unchecking the 'Hide Characters' option can help in ensuring the password is entered correctly.

To import settings from an old Peplink Balance 380 to a new one, it is essential to have a backup of the configuration file, which can be downloaded from the router's admin interface under System > Configuration > Download Active Configurations. If a backup is available, it can be imported into the new device. However, swapping the internal card between devices is not a viable option. Regularly backing up the configuration after changes is recommended for ease of recovery.

query: What are the key technical differences and considerations when choosing between the Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini (HW3), MAX BR1 Pro LTE-A, and MAX BR1 Pro 5G for high-throughput, multi-carrier, and future-proof deployments?
answer:
When selecting between the Pepwave MAX BR1 Mini (HW3), MAX BR1 Pro LTE-A, and MAX BR1 Pro 5G for high-throughput, multi-carrier, and future-proof deployments, it is important to consider several technical factors:

The MAX BR1 Mini (HW3) has a rated throughput of 300 Mbps, even though its WAN port is 1 Gbps; real-world TCP throughput is typically about 270–300 Mbps. Enabling additional features on the Mini can further reduce throughput, sometimes as low as 50 Mbps. The Mini uses Wi-Fi 5, supports nano SIM cards, and requires a failover license for Wi-Fi WAN. It is compatible with both AT&T and Verizon, and supports LTE and LTE-A variants for band compatibility, but does not support the latest bands such as T-Mobile's Band 71 or FirstNet Band 14. The LTE-A version is recommended for faster speeds and better band support.

The MAX BR1 Pro LTE-A offers up to 200 Mbps router throughput and provides a better LTE-A experience compared to the Mini. It supports more advanced LTE-A features and is certified for FirstNet (Band 14), making it suitable for public safety and advanced carrier deployments. The Pro LTE-A is also more future-proof than the Mini due to its expanded band support.

The MAX BR1 Pro 5G is the most advanced, featuring a Cat 20 5G modem, 2.5 Gbps WAN/LAN port, up to 1 Gbps throughput, and 5G/4G LTE compatibility. It supports band 71 (T-Mobile) and FirstNet (Band 14), offers five-band carrier aggregation for downloads, and uses Wi-Fi 6 for improved wireless performance. It is backwards compatible with 4G LTE, supports dual nano SIMs, and is designed for maximum future-proofing and multi-carrier deployments. It also features enhanced antenna options, GPS, and accessories for installation flexibility.

In summary, the BR1 Mini is cost-effective for basic LTE/LTE-A needs, the BR1 Pro LTE-A suits higher performance and public safety, while the BR1 Pro 5G is the optimal choice for highest throughput, latest band support, and future-proofing in demanding, multi-carrier environments.

Enabling additional features on the Mini can reduce throughput significantly, sometimes as low as 50 Mbps.
The Mini uses Wi-Fi 5, supports nano SIM cards, and requires a failover license for Wi-Fi WAN.
The Mini is compatible with AT&T and Verizon and supports LTE and LTE-A variants for broader band compatibility.
The LTE-A version of the Mini is recommended for better speeds and broader band support, especially for upgraded LTE spectrum.
The MAX BR1 Pro LTE-A offers up to 200 Mbps router throughput and is certified for FirstNet (Band 14).
The MAX BR1 Pro 5G features a Cat 20 5G modem, 2.5 Gbps WAN/LAN port, up to 1 Gbps throughput, supports band 71 and FirstNet (Band 14), and uses Wi-Fi 6.
The MAX BR1 Pro 5G supports five-band carrier aggregation, dual nano SIMs, and is backwards compatible with 4G LTE.

The Balance 20 may not handle high traffic volumes gracefully, and it is suggested that a more capable device, such as the Balance 20X, would be better suited for handling multiple simultaneous activities without performance degradation.

The Balance 20 router has a maximum throughput of 150Mbps, which can be exceeded by a 500Mbps WAN connection, potentially leading to performance issues such as high CPU usage and unresponsiveness during large downloads. Users have reported that actual throughput under real-world conditions can be significantly lower than the advertised specifications, with some suggesting that actual throughput may be about one-third of the raw throughput under ideal conditions. In contrast, other Peplink devices, like the Balance 20X, can achieve higher throughput, with reports of 900+ Mbps on 1Gbps fiber connections.

There is a configuration migration tool available for migrating settings between the Peplink Balance 30L and Balance 20 models, but it is not publicly accessible and can be obtained through Peplink support.

To successfully upgrade a Peplink Balance 305 HW2 from firmware version 8.0.0 to 8.3.0, it is recommended to perform a gradual update through intermediate versions. The suggested intermediate firmware versions to try are 8.0.1, 8.1.0, 8.1.2, and 8.2.0, as attempting to upgrade directly to 8.3.0 may result in errors such as 'Firmware check pending' or 'invalid firmware image.'

The Peplink Balance 700, released in 2006, is considered outdated and should be replaced for security reasons. If one chooses to keep it, the minimum recommended firmware version is 6.3.4, which requires upgrading through several intermediate versions: 5.0, 5.3.12, and 5.4.9 before reaching 6.1.0 and finally 6.3.4. The firmware for version 5 is not publicly available and requires logging a support ticket to obtain.

The throughput on the Peplink Balance 20 is limited to 150 Mbps, which may restrict the performance when connected to higher-speed WANs like a 200 Mbps cable modem or a 400 Mbps T-Mobile 5G gateway. The Balance 20 allows for traffic management by enabling users to send traffic from a specific device, identified by MAC address, to a designated WAN through its Outbound Policy feature, which is a powerful tool for managing network traffic.

If there is packet loss on a Peplink Balance 5G device caused by a physical hardware fault, an RMA (Return Merchandise Authorization) can be obtained. Peplink engineering will validate the issue remotely before approving the RMA through the distributor.

The Balance 20 is rated for 30MBps of IPSEC VPN throughput, while OpenVPN typically has lower performance due to higher CPU overhead. The performance issue experienced with OpenVPN on the Balance 20 may be expected given these limitations. The Balance 20X's specifications regarding multi-CPU/core capabilities are uncertain, but it is suggested that upgrading may improve performance.

To successfully configure a Vodafone Germany SIM card in a Peplink Balance X20, the correct APN settings must be used. The APN should be set to 'web.vodafone.de' for contract users, 'event.vodafone.de' for web sessions, CallYa, and prepaid users, and 'home.vodafone.de' for Vodafone GigaCube. Additionally, the primary DNS should be set to 139.007.030.125 and the secondary DNS to 139.007.030.126.
To flush the DNS on a Peplink Balance Core, the only current methods are to wait for the DNS records to expire or to reboot the device. Improvements to this process are planned for the future.

For users seeking stability over speed in their Peplink Balance 20X solutions, it is suggested to consider adding a Cat 18 or Cat 20 (5G) module alongside the built-in Cat 4 modem. This setup allows for bonding multiple connections using SpeedFusion technology, which can enhance reliability by providing redundant carriers. This configuration is particularly beneficial for applications requiring continuous streaming, such as a 64-bit AAC audio stream running 24/7.

To integrate Peplink BAL-1350 and Peplink Balance 380 with Solarwinds SIEM, first enable SNMP on the BAL-1350. Then, install the custom MIBs from the Peplink support downloads page into Solarwinds. Finally, configure Solarwinds to point at the BAL-1350 for monitoring.

After switching from a Balance 30 LTE to a Balance 20X router, network printers (HP 5740) went offline, and errors occurred when attempting to print. Windows can detect the printers and install their drivers, but printing fails. There are known issues with Windows updates causing problems with network printing, particularly after recent updates, which may be contributing to the issue. Testing with older versions of Windows could help determine if the router is the source of the problem.

For a Balance 2500 router experiencing a constant high frequency beeping sound, it is suggested that a PSU replacement may be necessary if the router is configured with dual PSUs. The status light on the PSU should be checked, with a normal PSU indicated by a green light. Additionally, the beeping sound can be turned off by pressing the red button located on the rear panel of the Balance 2500.

To enable connectivity from PepLink Balance 305 devices to Azure through a Balance 508, static routes can be configured on the Balance 305 for the Azure subnet, using the Balance 508 as the gateway. Additionally, the Azure configuration should include a static route for the Balance 305 subnet, also using the Balance 508 as the gateway. It is important to ensure that firewall rules on both ends permit this routing to function correctly.

In a network setup involving multiple PepLink Balance 305 devices connected to a Balance 508 via a star topology, issues may arise with route advertisement to Azure through IP Sec VPN tunnels. The Balance 508 may not be advertising its routes to the connected Balance 305 devices, which can prevent satellite sites from accessing Azure. Additionally, static routes may need to connect to gateways within the same subnet, which can complicate configurations if sites are not willing to share a common subnet.

In a network configuration involving multiple PepLink Balance 305 routers connected to a Balance 508 via IP Sec VPN tunnels to Azure, it is important to ensure that outbound rules are correctly set up for traffic to traverse from the satellite sites to Azure. The Balance 508 needs to properly advertise its routes to the connected 305 devices for successful end-to-end connectivity.

The outbound policy configuration on the PepLink Balance 508 was successfully adjusted, allowing the connected Balance 305 devices to traverse to Azure through the established IP Sec VPN tunnels. This indicates that proper routing and policy settings are essential for enabling connectivity between satellite sites and Azure.
To monitor WAN interfaces on a Peplink model BPL-380 using SNMP with PRTG, users can find the necessary MIB files on the Peplink support downloads page.

The Peplink Balance One Core router is designed to support throughput up to 600Mbps, but users have reported varying performance levels, with one user experiencing a drop from 450Mbps to 260Mbps despite confirming that the issue is not with the ISP. The user has attempted various troubleshooting steps, including disconnecting devices, disabling PepVPN tunnels, and downgrading firmware, but the throughput remains low. Additionally, there are discrepancies in the router's specifications on different pages, with some showing a maximum throughput of 400Mbps instead of the expected 600Mbps.

When using a Peplink Balance 30 Pro with a Verizon SIM to serve a network of over 100 computers, issues with throughput may arise despite good ping times and download speeds when only a few devices are connected. Potential causes for the low throughput could include the limitations of the Verizon plan being used, as many mobile data plans are not designed for enterprise router use. It is advisable to check traffic statistics to identify if any single device is consuming excessive bandwidth and to conduct tests with fewer devices to isolate the issue.

To successfully build SpeedFusion tunnels, it is necessary to connect to WAN interfaces of Peplink appliances. In this case, placing VLAN 200 on the Balance 580's WAN3 interface is recommended to enable the bonding of LTE and BLR WAN interfaces from the remote site B30Pro with the WAN 1 interface at HQ.

On the Peplink Balance two, the LAN/WAN light may not illuminate if there is no connectivity or if the link is operating at 10 or 100 Mbps. This behavior is documented in the May 2020 manual for Balance models.

To enhance security on Peplink Balance one routers, it is recommended to change the default inbound firewall rule to deny all. If there is a need for specific inbound access, allow rules can be created above the default deny rule.

The Peplink 310X does not support Jumbo Frames, as this feature is only available in the Balance 305 and higher models. However, users should check the latest firmware updates, specifically firmware version 8.1.1 Beta 2, for any potential changes or improvements regarding this feature.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a throughput of 150Mbps, which is less than the combined total of the user's WAN connections (100/5M, 150/6M, and 35/5M). For users with 20-30 connections, particularly for applications like Zoom, upgrading to a Peplink Balance 305 is recommended due to its higher capacity and performance, supporting up to 1Gbps throughput. Alternatively, the Balance 210 with an additional license can provide a maximum throughput of 350Mbps, but it is not as capable as the Balance 305.

The Balance 20 router is rated for a maximum throughput of 150Mbps, but its VPN throughput with encryption is limited to 30Mbps. In contrast, the Balance 20x model offers a higher VPN throughput of 60Mbps. However, the Balance 20x does not support firmware version 7, which may be a consideration for users experiencing issues with firmware 8. The Balance One is another alternative that can run firmware 7, but its VPN throughput specifications are not published. Users should consider the bandwidth requirements for their VPN connections, as actual throughput will likely be less than the maximum capacity of the internet connection.

The issue with the Ethernet Port status display showing incorrect information on the Balance 310XX Series has been fixed in the 8.1.0 beta 1 build. Users are advised to upgrade to 8.1.0 beta 4 to resolve this issue.

When using a Balance 78A3 router on a gigabit Ethernet LAN with a 200 Mb Spectrum service, if only 9 Mbps internet speeds are observed, it may indicate an issue with the router's configuration or compatibility with the ISP's equipment. The router's port speeds should be set to 1 Gbps Full Duplex, but if it only operates at 100 Mbps, testing with a gigabit switch between the Balance 78A3 and the ISP router could help identify potential incompatibilities.

The Balance 20X router, when running firmware version 8.0.1 build 1032, achieves WAN to LAN throughput of approximately 900Mbps. However, after upgrading to firmware version 8.0.2 build 1045, the throughput drops to around 550Mbps, which is similar to the performance of the Balance One. In contrast, after upgrading to firmware version 8.1.0b02, WAN to LAN throughput speeds can reach as high as 925Mbps, indicating improved performance over the previous version.
The Peplink Balance B1 does not have an integrated DSL modem, meaning a separate modem is required to connect a DSL line to the Balance device.

The Peplink Balance One is rated for 600Mbps throughput, but the user is experiencing download speeds between 260Mbps and 303Mbps, which is significantly lower than expected. In contrast, a pfSense box connected in the same manner achieves over 500Mbps download speeds, indicating that the issue may not be with the internet connection itself, as there are no errors or collisions reported on the Peplink device.

In a Peplink 710 HA (High Availability) setup, the slave unit is designed to receive configuration changes from the master unit automatically within 5 minutes after a change is made. This feature allows for synchronization of settings without requiring manual intervention, although there may be a perceived limitation if immediate synchronization is expected.

The Peplink Balance 300, which is approximately 15 years old, supports a maximum throughput of 20Mbps. Therefore, if clients are experiencing a maximum speed of 15Mbps, this is within the expected performance limits of the device, despite having three WAN connections with a total potential speed of 300Mbps.

The Balance 300 router supports a maximum throughput of 20mbps per user, despite having three WAN connections each capable of 100mbps. This means that while the total potential speed from the WAN connections is 300mbps, the router's limitations restrict the actual usable speed to 20mbps per user, indicating that the additional bandwidth from the WAN connections is not utilized effectively.

Devices can be configured to use arbitrary MAC addresses, which can result in a MAC address not being linked to any manufacturer. While setting up deny rules for a MAC address can prevent that device from communicating on the network, it is not considered a robust security measure. It is advisable to investigate the unknown device further to determine its identity and connection method.

To facilitate communication between PC #2 and a cable modem using a Peplink Balance 200, it is suggested to create a custom outbound rule with the destination IP of 192.168.100.1 and enforce it on the Cable WAN connection.

To aggregate bandwidth between three sites using Peplink solutions, the Balance 1350 can be deployed, which supports 350 Mbps of SpeedFusion VPN throughput. The expected combined bandwidth between Plant 2 and Plant 3 is approximately 165 Mbps, while the VPN to Plant 1 can achieve around 103 Mbps, leading to a potential total of 268 Mbps for simultaneous upload/download SpeedFusion VPN throughput. It is recommended to use layer 3 SpeedFusion VPNs, accounting for about 10% overhead due to encryption, and to consider new features in firmware version 6.2, such as WAN smoothing, for improved performance.

To upgrade a Peplink Balance 30 LTE from firmware version 6.1.2 to 7.1.2, users should ensure that the firmware upload is successful. If the online upgrade method fails, the manual upgrade method can be attempted by directing the device to the correct .bin file for the firmware version. Users should verify that the firmware image is compatible and that the upload process is functioning correctly, as issues may arise if the upload does not progress or if the device remains on the previous firmware version after the attempt.

The latest hardware version for the Peplink Balance series is HW3, as indicated on the firmware update page. Users considering an upgrade should verify if their current unit's specifications align with the latest models available.

The Peplink Balance 20 is designed for small office or branch environments and is recommended for up to 60 users. In larger network environments, using a Balance router with a higher capacity is advisable to prevent interruptions. The Balance 20 may struggle with handling traffic loads effectively, especially when multiple clients are connected and NATed by another router.

The Balance 20 router has a maximum throughput of 150Mbps, which is insufficient for users with ISPs offering speeds of 600Mbps and plans for 1000Mbps in the near future. Users are inquiring about potential upgrades for the Balance 20 to support higher throughput speeds or the necessity of upgrading to the Balance 305 to accommodate increasing ISP speeds. There is concern regarding the cost-effectiveness of purchasing a new router that may soon become obsolete as ISPs continue to enhance their offerings.

Different routers have varying throughput capabilities, which can affect the speeds experienced when using devices like the Peplink Balance 20. To achieve optimal speeds, it is important to consider the specifications of the router and how they compare to the connection being used. For detailed comparisons, users can refer to the Peplink model comparison page.

To successfully upgrade the firmware on a Peplink Balance 30 from version 5.3.12 to 7.1.0, it is necessary to follow the correct firmware upgrade path: first upgrade to 5.4.9 before proceeding to 7.1.0. Archived firmware versions can be obtained from the Peplink support downloads archive.

To upgrade a Peplink Balance 30 from firmware version 5.3.12 build 1303 to the latest firmware 7.1.0, it is necessary to first upgrade to firmware release 5.4.9 to avoid potential issues during the upgrade process.

In a drop-in mode deployment of the PepLink Balance 380, the DHCP Server settings will be overwritten. Typically, a firewall with public IPs is positioned on the inside of the Balance, and DHCP is managed on the inside of the firewall.
Enabling VLANs on a Balance 1350 router does not cause any downtime, allowing for configuration changes without interrupting the network service.

To successfully upgrade a Pepwave Balance 710 from firmware version 4.8.2 to 6.3.4, it is necessary to first upgrade to version 5.3.12. The archived firmware can be found on the Peplink support downloads page.

To set Quality of Service (QoS) on a Peplink BalanceOne router via SSID, you can utilize the QoS Bandwidth Control feature. This involves setting up a VLAN for the specific SSID under QoS > User Groups, and then defining the bandwidth limits for each user in that group through QoS > Bandwidth Controls.

In a network setup involving a PepLink Balance One, if an ISP's modem is seeing internal LAN IP addresses, it is important to check the Routing Mode for WAN1. The mode should be set to NAT (Network Address Translation) rather than IP-Forwarding to ensure that only the PepLink's IP address is visible to the ISP's modem, concealing the internal LAN IP addresses from being exposed.

It is not possible to convert the configuration from a PepLink Balance 310 to a PepLink Balance 210. Additionally, it is important to confirm whether a 3rd WAN activation license has been purchased for the Balance 210 router.

To configure a SpeedFusion tunnel from a Peplink PL380A in Layer 3 mode to a PL580, and a second SpeedFusion tunnel in Layer 2 mode from the PL380A to a PL380B, it is necessary to ensure that the IP addressing is correctly set up. For Layer 2 configurations, both sites should not use the same IP address and gateway; instead, they should have distinct gateway IPs, such as 192.168.50.1 for Site 1 and a different address for Site 2, to avoid conflicts and ensure proper routing.

In a situation where a Peplink B380 router is not supplying DNS, it is observed that while traffic is passing through both WAN ports, clients are unable to access the internet. Pinging external IP addresses returns replies, indicating that the issue is DNS-related rather than a complete loss of connectivity. The DNS proxy, DNS caching, and public DNS records options are enabled, but some LAN clients are found to be using public DNS servers instead of the configured DNS proxy. Rebooting the B380 temporarily resolves the issue, and testing with an earlier firmware version (7.0.1) is planned to see if it alleviates the problem.

For users of the Pepwave Balance One running firmware version 6.3.3, upgrading to version 6.3.4 is recommended for security fixes, while upgrading to version 7.1.0 provides new features, security enhancements, and performance improvements. It is important to consider hardware compatibility and to back up configurations and admin passwords before performing any firmware upgrades.

For load balancing with different WAN technologies such as DSL, Fiber, and Vsat, with a throughput requirement of more than 2GB, the Peplink BPL-710 or BPL-1350 Max models are suitable options. These models support NAT for all WAN ports and can reroute traffic from a congested or failed link to other WAN links with different NAT configurations. However, specific information regarding failover for WAN links and NAT resolution for users when one of the WAN links goes down is not provided.

Configurations from a Peplink Balance 1350 cannot be directly uploaded to a Balance 30 due to differences in model specifications. While Peplink engineering can convert configurations between device models upon request, this process is time-consuming and not suitable for immediate backup needs. It is recommended to manually replicate configurations that can be copied as changes are made to the Balance 1350.

To set up Peplink Balance VPNs for mobile smart devices using public unencrypted WiFi, it is important to configure the L2TP/IPSEC Preshared Key and the User account password correctly. This ensures secure communication over public networks.
All versions of the Peplink B310 are compatible with the latest firmware, indicating that there are no limitations on firmware upgrades for this model.
The default login credentials for the Peplink Balance 1 router are username 'admin' and password 'admin'.

The throughput displayed on a Balance device indicates the maximum performance capability of the router, which can vary between models. The Balance 20 has a specified throughput of 150Mbps, which may limit speed tests to around that value, while the Balance 30, which is likely a hardware version 3 with LTE capabilities, shows a throughput of 200Mbps but can achieve higher speed test results, such as 467Mbps. This discrepancy may be due to outdated performance information on the manufacturer's website.
The Balance 30-20 does not support reverse proxy functionality. However, inbound load balancing is supported on the Balance 210 and above models.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a throughput rating of 150Mbps, which may become a bottleneck given the total WAN bandwidth of 350/250 Mbps. It excels in load balancing in multi-WAN environments and is recommended to use PepVPN/SpeedFusion instead of IPsec for better performance. For redundancy, it is suggested to use the Balance 20 primarily for NAT, as it may not handle the full bandwidth effectively. A configuration option includes using the cable modem on WAN 1 in drop-in mode and connecting the fiber to WAN 2, allowing the Balance to act as an ARP proxy for failover. This setup would provide public IP access from the cable modem while maintaining backup capabilities with the fiber connection.

In a lab environment with a B310 and B1350 running firmware version 7.0.1, traffic is intended to be split across three links based on source/destination policies. However, the second and third tunnels are inactive, and traffic is defaulting to route 1, indicating that the policies are not functioning as expected. The placement of the routing rules may affect their behavior, with a suggestion that they should be positioned below the PepVPN route section. Additionally, failure detection settings were adjusted to minimize traffic across the links, with only minimal ping traffic being sent.

To route traffic to a 10.x.x.x network using a PepLink 305, it is necessary to add static routes for those networks on the Balance Core, setting the gateway or next hop to the WAN IP of the private network router. It may be more efficient to change the LAN B VLAN to a 192 or 172 subnet and create a single static route for the entire 10.0.0.0/8 block.
The latest firmware for the Peplink Balance 20W is v4.8.1, and this model has been obsoleted. Users are advised to consider refreshing their router for updated features and support.

To obtain a Peplink FusionHub trial key, users should refer to the user manual available online. The Peplink Balance 1350 supports WAN load balancing through SpeedFusion Bonding with FusionHub, allowing for enhanced connectivity on remote servers.

The firmware for the Peplink Balance 50 is the same as that for the Balance 20 and Balance 30. The correct firmware version 7.0.0 can be downloaded from the URL https://download.peplink.com/firmware/plb30/fw-b20_30-7.0.0-build3310.bin. There was an error in the URL for the firmware on the Peplink website, and the firmware for version 6.3.3 also contains incorrect links. The best representation of firmware for these models is found in version 6.2.3, where the models have been consolidated into one button on the download page.

When managing IP address rules in the Inbound Firewall section of a PepLink Balance 300, excessive rules can lead to performance issues, such as slow loading times and network timeouts on the management interface. It is suggested to review the list for dynamic addresses that may no longer be relevant, as these can clutter the rule set. Reducing the number of rules may improve the interface's responsiveness, and there may be options for assistance from engineers to replace existing rule sets with more efficient configurations.
Applying the 3-5 license to the Peplink Balance Core results in the permanent activation of 5 WAN ports and provides a total of 5 LAN ports.

To upgrade the firmware on a Peplink Balance 700 from version 4, the device must first be updated to version 4.8.2, then to 5.3.12, and finally to the highest version 5.4.9. Users are advised to open a support ticket for specific links and instructions regarding the firmware upgrade process.

To resolve a persistent red status LED on a Peplink BLP310, it is recommended to perform a factory reset by holding the pin reset button for approximately 10-15 seconds while the device is powered on. If the issue persists after the reset, it is advisable to open a support ticket for further assistance from the technical team.

The Peplink Balance 20 may not be adequate for a dermatology clinic experiencing connectivity issues due to increased traffic from multiple devices, including 12 iPads and various networked equipment. The current setup includes two WAN connections, a Comcast connection at 75Mb and a Century Link DSL at 7.5Mb, with plans to upgrade to potentially 500Mb to 1Gb on Century Link and 100Mb on Comcast. Given these anticipated throughput requirements, it is recommended to consider upgrading to a Peplink Balance 305 or Balance 380, especially if SpeedFusion bonding is needed.

The Balance 30 LTE has a maximum throughput of 150Mbps, which is a hardware limitation that cannot be exceeded. For users needing higher speeds, upgrading to a Balance One or Balance 305 is recommended, and Peplink support can assist in converting the configuration file to the new model.

To enhance WAN capabilities for a branch using a B210, it is recommended to consider a Balance 580 if five WAN connections are needed for internet load balancing. The combination of a B50 with a B210 is not explicitly supported for this purpose, and using multiple devices may complicate the SpeedFusion tunnel setup. There is no mention of a buyback program for upgrading equipment in the provided information.

The Peplink BPL 210 and BPL 30 can establish a site-to-site VPN, indicated by a green VPN icon, allowing successful pings between the routers' LAN IPs. However, issues arise when attempting to ping hosts within the respective networks, suggesting potential configuration problems related to LAN subnets, VLANs, or WAN connections.

To resolve issues with pinging hosts across a site-to-site VPN between two Peplink devices (BPL 210 and BPL 30), it is necessary to adjust the firewall settings. By default, the firewall may block traffic, so an inbound rule should be added to allow traffic from the LAN (e.g., 192.168.0.0/24) to any destination. This rule needs to be configured on both devices to enable communication between the networks.

When experiencing slow download speeds with a Peplink Balance 20 Router, it is important to check the configuration settings, including WAN interface settings which should be set to Auto/Auto for proper connection to the carrier router. In cases where bandwidth degradation occurs only when the Peplink is in use, it may be beneficial to investigate the Peplink interfaces for errors or performance issues, as well as to ensure that outbound policies and bandwidth limits are not inadvertently affecting performance. Additionally, using Drop-in mode may impact the routing and performance, so reviewing this setup could also be necessary.

The Peplink Balance 20 router has a maximum rated throughput of 100 Mbps, which is likely causing the observed throughput limitation when connected to a 250 Mbps cable connection. For higher throughput needs, upgrading to a Peplink Balance One, which supports over 600 Mbps, is recommended.

For load balancing and failover of two 15Mb DSL connections with 15 users and 50 devices including VoIP and VPN support, the PepLink Balance 030 may not be adequate as it is recommended for up to 25 simultaneous users/devices. The Balance One is suggested as a more suitable option for this configuration.

For bonding and failover of ISP connections in a data center setup, Peplink devices like the BPL-135 or BPL-2500 can be utilized. The devices can be configured for active/active failover with multiple ISP connections. However, specific license fees for load balancing and bonding should be confirmed with Peplink. It is possible to bond return traffic, but this typically requires Peplink devices at both ends of the connection. To maintain VPN connections during ISP WAN drops, proper configuration of the Peplink devices is essential. Additionally, Peplink devices can function as DNS servers.

Peplink lists several USB modems from AT&T that are compatible with their Balance Routers, including models such as the AT&T Mobile Hotspot Elevate 4G, MiFi Liberate, and various Sierra Wireless and LG devices. However, the listed modems may not include the latest AT&T products like the AT&T Beam, Unite Pro, Unite, and Velocity. For issues with USB dongle compatibility, users are encouraged to open a support ticket with Peplink for assistance.

To upgrade a Peplink Balance 30 from firmware version 4.8.1 build 1106 to the latest firmware version 6.x, the upgrade must be performed in a specific sequence. First, upgrade to firmware version 5.2.2, then to 5.4.10 build 1769, and finally to 6.1.2 build 2717.

To issue public IPs to clients using a Peplink router, it is important to configure the router to allow the billing gateway to handle 1:1 NAT. If the internet fails on WAN1, the public IPs on the LAN will NAT to the public IPs on WAN2. However, IP forwarding cannot be used on more than one WAN with public IPs. Load balancing and failover can be managed through outbound policy rules in the Peplink Balance router.
To insert firewall rules for SSH in a PePLink 310, navigate to Network, then Access Rules, and select either Inbound Firewall Rules or Outbound Firewall Rules to add a new rule.

After performing a factory reset on a Peplink Balance 320, the default IP address to access the web interface is 192.168.1.1, with both the username and password set to 'admin'. This is important to note as the previous configuration settings, including the IP address, will no longer apply after a reset.

The issue of not receiving an HTTP 200 response when accessing specific web pages on a Peplink Balance 580 could be related to a WAN MTU issue, suggesting that adjusting the MTU size to a smaller value, such as 1440 or 1400, may help. Additionally, DNS settings or the need for an outbound policy rule could also be contributing factors. If the problem persists, it is recommended to open a support ticket for further investigation.

It is possible to perform a configuration conversion between Peplink Balance 300 and Balance 380 devices. Users can send the configuration file from the Balance 300 to Peplink's technical support team for assistance with the conversion process.

To resolve an IP address conflict when connecting a Windstream router to a Peplink Balance30, the interface IP of the Peplink must be different from the internal IP address of the Windstream router. This can be achieved by changing the Peplink's interface IP, changing the Windstream router's internal IP address, or by putting the Windstream router into bridge mode to pass the public IP to the Peplink Balance30. Each ISP modem should be connected to the appropriate WAN ports on the Peplink, and the connection type can be set to either DHCP or Static.

SpeedFusion does not redistribute routes for IPSEC profiles. To enable communication between SpeedFusion endpoints and an IPSEC network, an Outbound policy must be added for the IPSEC destination networks over the appropriate SpeedFusion tunnel.

The Peplink Balance e30 is not a DSL modem and does not have RJ11 ports; it only features RJ45 Ethernet ports. To connect the Balance router to an ADSL connection, a separate DSL modem is required that provides an Ethernet output to connect to the Balance's WAN port.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a bandwidth limit of 100 Mbps, which may be a concern if WAN speeds increase significantly in the future. The device supports PePVPN in the new 6.1 firmware, providing session persistence but lacking WAN aggregation features found in SpeedFusion. The Balance 20 does not offer user or group bandwidth limitations, which may be a drawback for users needing to allocate minimum bandwidth to specific devices. Additionally, the Balance 20 can handle two WAN connections, one with two static IP addresses and another with a dynamic IP, ensuring proper routing to separate LAN devices.

To safely upgrade from Peplink firmware version 4.8 to 5.4, it is recommended to follow a specific upgrade path: first upgrade to firmware version 5.0, then to 5.3.12, and finally to 5.4.9. Additionally, it is important to have the unlock key ready before upgrading to any 5.x release.

To upgrade from firmware version 4.8 to 5.4 on a Peplink device, it is advisable to refer to the Peplink knowledge base for specific instructions regarding the upgrade process. This includes checking for any necessary updates or unlock keys that may be required during the upgrade to ensure a smooth transition with minimal downtime.

After a power loss, if a Peplink Balance 30 device does not respond via the web interface but is still reachable via ping, it is recommended to attempt a factory reset and then access the device using the default IP address 192.168.1.1 with the credentials admin/admin. If the login prompt is not accessible, trying different web browsers like Chrome or Firefox may resolve compatibility issues, as Internet Explorer may not function properly with some interfaces.

The Peplink Balance 1350 supports only one VLAN, necessitating a layer 3 switch for additional VLAN configurations. With firmware release 6.1, multiple LAN subnets will be supported. The Balance 1350 can manage up to 20 access points (APs) without an additional license, while a license is required for controlling between 21 and 500 APs. The device is scalable and can handle over 5000 users, accommodating future growth needs.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a router throughput rating of 100 Mbps, which is a limiting factor for the maximum speed experienced when connected through the device. The Balance 20 features 4 Gigabit Ethernet (GbE) LAN ports, but the overall throughput is determined by the router's specifications. Users should consider the total throughput by adding the upload and download speeds of all WAN connections to understand performance limitations.

To achieve higher download speeds with a Peplink Balance router, it is recommended to use a Balance 305 or a model rated for higher throughput, as the Balance 20 is rated for a maximum of 200Mbps. This may explain the slower speeds experienced when routing through the Peplink device compared to a direct connection to the ISP's router.

When using a Peplink Balance 210 with two WAN connections, a user reported a significant drop in download speeds from 100mbps to 30mbps when routing through the device. The user noted that directly connecting to the cable connection yielded expected speeds, but the Peplink device limited the throughput to a maximum of 9mbps, raising concerns about the performance and capability of the router given its price point.

The Balance 380 has a router throughput rating of 200 Mbps, which indicates that the combined WAN upload and download speeds can potentially exceed this limit, leading to undesirable behavior. Although the router should sustain 75 Mbps of throughput, high CPU load can occur under certain conditions, affecting performance and causing issues such as failed admin page requests and internet unavailability for other users. It is advisable to open a support ticket for further investigation.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a router throughput rating of 100 Mbps, which is sufficient for the combined bandwidth of the user's Comcast and Century Link DSL connections, totaling slightly over 50 Mbps. The device can support 1-25 LAN clients, making it suitable for the anticipated growth to 21 clients (9 VoIP lines and 12 computers). The primary bottleneck in this setup is likely the Century Link DSL connection, especially considering the daily internet traffic of 2-3 GB, which is manageable given the available bandwidth. The Balance 20 should continue to perform well under the current and projected usage, with the option to upgrade later if necessary.

The Peplink Balance 20 is capable of handling internet speeds up to 100Mbps, making it suitable for home or small office use. It is recommended as a newer model to replace the older Balance Plus unit, which may not support faster internet speeds.

To improve internet connectivity and provide failover support at remote offices, replacing Juniper devices with Peplink devices, specifically the Balance 20/30, is suggested. SpeedFusion VPN Bonding can combine multiple internet connections at each remote site for enhanced bandwidth. However, SpeedFusion is a premium feature that incurs additional costs. For remote users to connect to the network, further guidance on setup is needed, as no tutorials have been found on this specific configuration.

After upgrading a MAX BR1 from firmware version 6.0.3 to 6.1.2, the PepVPN tunnels to another BR1 and a PepLink Balance 30 stop functioning, indicated by a spinning icon on the dashboard. Downgrading back to 6.0.3 restores the tunnels' functionality. The issue persists with the upgrade to 6.1 from 6.0.3, suggesting a potential compatibility or configuration issue with the PepVPN tunnels in the newer firmware version.

The Peplink HD4 currently supports only 2 WAN connections and does not offer a license upgrade to enable additional WAN ports, unlike the Peplink Balancer One which has a license feature for 5 WAN ports.

To troubleshoot connectivity issues between a Pepwave MAX HD2 and a Pepwave B1350, it is recommended to simplify the setup by directly connecting the WAN ports of both devices. Assign static IPs to the WAN interfaces from the same subnet and configure the health check to 'ping' with the target set to the WAN IP of the other device. This approach may help in identifying the problem with the IPSec and SpeedFusion tunnels not connecting and the lack of authentication logs.

The Pepwave BR1 is a fail-over only device, meaning it can only route traffic through a single interface at any given time. For simultaneous routing of traffic through both the WAN and LTE ports, a different model such as the Balance 30 LTE or a multi-cellular router would be required for load balancing capabilities.

The recommended user capacity for the Peplink Balance 20/30 and Surf SOHO devices is about 25 users simultaneously, with a maximum throughput of 100Mbps. The Surf SOHO is a fail-over only device, allowing only one active connection at a time, while the Balance series supports multiple connections and load balancing. For scenarios involving growth and higher demand, it is advisable to consider the Balance 210/310 or Balance 305 models, which can accommodate future needs more effectively.

Harrington Plastics upgraded its network infrastructure by replacing its aging MPLS circuits with Peplink solutions, specifically the Peplink Balance 1350 and Balance 380, achieving significant cost savings of $100,000 annually. The new setup provides 4 times the bandwidth, seamless hardware failover, and a highly available network due to WAN diversity. The network is supported by a pair of redundant Balance 1530s at the corporate office and 4G USB modems at branches, creating an Unbreakable VPN connection. The total bandwidth increased from 36 Mbps to 138 Mbps, demonstrating the effectiveness of the Peplink solution in delivering reliable and cost-effective networking.
