However, while Peplink appliances are primarily SD-WAN devices with reliable firewall capabilities, they may not fully replace the functionality of existing SRX firewalls. It is recommended to conduct thorough testing and refer to technical documentation for deployment guidance.

To verify the functionality of a PEPVPN connection between two Peplink Balance 20 routers, one can perform a ping test from a PC on one network to the LAN IP of the other router. If the ping is successful, it indicates that the VPN is operational. Additionally, users can log into the web UI of Balance Router A, navigate to System -> Tools, and use the ping feature to test connectivity to the LAN of Balance Router B. This process can be repeated from the B network to confirm the VPN connection.

To optimize WAN performance on a Peplink Balance 20, users should configure outbound policies to manage traffic effectively. Setting the default weighted balance to 1 for both WAN connections can help in balancing TCP connections across the two WANs. This configuration allows for better utilization of available bandwidth from both xDSL and 4G connections.

To manage outbound policies for devices using streaming services like Netflix and Hulu on a Peplink Balance 30, it is suggested to create rules based on the source IP of the devices rather than relying solely on destination domains, especially for complex domains like those associated with Amazon Web Services. This can be achieved by setting the source to the specific IP address of the device, allowing for more precise control over the outbound connection used for those devices.

To set up a Peplink 30 with WAN1 configured for Bell Canada fiber and multiple static IPs, ensure that the outside Gateway is defined correctly on the Peplink. For WAN1, the static IP is 66.x.x.148 with a subnet of 255.255.255.252/30 and a Gateway of 66.x.x.147. The usable static IPs for WAN1 are 204.x.x.129 with a subnet of 255.255.255.240/28 and a Gateway of 204.x.x.129, allowing for static IPs ranging from 204.x.x.130 to 142. For WAN2, which is connected to Videotron, only one static IP is obtained since the Gateway is set on a Videotron router. NAT configuration may be necessary for proper routing and IP management.

In a Peplink setup using session-based load balancing, if WAN2 and WAN3 fail, active sessions will not persist due to the IP change, and all packets will not route through WAN1 without loss. SpeedFusion technology can bond all WAN connections, allowing for seamless packet routing to other links if one WAN fails, thus preventing loss of active sessions. For the Overflow load balancing algorithm, Peplink considers only the downstream bandwidth utilization of each WAN link to determine routing according to the configured Overflow priority.

A Peplink Balance 20 or 30 can combine both DSL and cable internet connections for load balancing and automatic failover, ensuring continuous connectivity. The AP One access points are suitable for enhancing wireless coverage in larger homes, utilizing TruePower RF technology for increased signal strength. The AP One operates on the 2.4GHz band, while the AP One mini supports 5GHz, which may require compatible devices for optimal performance.

The Peplink Balance 20 and 30 routers are rated for 100 Mbps of throughput, which includes both upload and download speeds. They support various types of WAN connections, including Ethernet and USB, although some USB connections may require a firmware update. The Balance series is designed to handle multiple WAN connections, ensuring seamless failover in case one connection drops.

Peplink routers balance network traffic between multiple WAN connections based on outbound policy settings. If the default rule is set to auto, traffic distribution occurs on a weighted balance basis, taking into account the downstream bandwidth of each WAN. To achieve better load balancing, it is important to verify the downstream bandwidth settings for each WAN in the web admin page under Network > WAN.

The Peplink Balance 30 is rated for a maximum throughput of 100Mbps for both upload and download speeds. If the combined speeds of the connected ISPs exceed this limit, performance issues may arise due to bottlenecking. For higher throughput needs, upgrading to a Peplink Balance 380, which supports up to 170Mbps, is recommended. The Peplink Balance can provide benefits such as traffic prioritization through load balancing, quality of service (QoS) assignment on an application or port level, and hardware firewall capabilities, enhancing overall network performance and flexibility.

To optimize internet speed on a Peplink Balance 310 with multiple WAN connections, it is recommended to create a weighted balance rule for all protocols, adjusting the weights according to the bandwidth of each connection. For example, a ratio of 7 for the 2Mbps connection and 10 for the 3Mbps connections may be effective. Specific outbound rules for individual protocols should be prioritized by placing them at the top of the rule list, as higher rules take precedence. This setup allows the Peplink router to distribute traffic effectively across all WAN links, potentially improving overall speed as all connections are utilized simultaneously.

On a Peplink Balance 20, outbound requests can be configured to utilize all WAN connections through the custom rules option. Aggregation of bandwidth occurs when the server supports multiple sessions, which is often the case with speed testing services like speedtest.net. This explains the difference in performance between two Balance 20 devices when using identical 25 Mbps ADSL2+ lines, where one is aggregating and the other is load balancing.

To configure a Peplink PEP20 with multiple WAN connections and static IPs, it is recommended to change the outbound policy to 'Managed by Custom Rules' for better control over traffic balancing. It is important to retain the default rules, such as HTTPS Persistence and the default weighted balance rule, which are based on the upstream and downstream bandwidth values set for each WAN connection.

To enable SpeedFusion between two sites using Peplink devices, it is possible to control traffic routing by using outbound policies, allowing for the selection of which traffic is sent over the bonded WAN connection while simultaneously directing other traffic directly to the internet outside of the bonding.

There is no official list of transceivers compatible with the Peplink Balance SDX, but users have found information through experimentation. A suggested starting point for compatibility information is a provided link, although it is noted that the information may be outdated and that some sources, like FiberStore, have been misleading.

To successfully upgrade a Peplink Balance 305 HW2 from firmware version 8.0.0 to 8.3.0, it is recommended to perform a gradual update through intermediate versions. The suggested intermediate firmware versions to try are 8.0.1, 8.1.0, 8.1.2, and 8.2.0, as attempting to upgrade directly to 8.3.0 may result in errors such as 'Firmware check pending' or 'invalid firmware image.'

Using two Peplink MAX BR1 PRO routers in series with Outbound Policy Weighted Balancing can achieve session balancing according to the defined ratio for each WAN. For true load balancing, Peplink devices can utilize per-packet load balancing through SpeedFusion technology, which helps mitigate issues if either WAN connection becomes degraded or fails.

When using a Peplink Balance 20 with multiple WAN connections, issues such as being kicked off a CPanel control panel or failing FTP uploads can occur due to load balancing, which alternates outbound connections between the WANs. This behavior can cause the receiving end to see different IP addresses, leading to connection problems. To resolve this, users can implement outbound policies that direct specific traffic to designated WANs, ensuring consistent IP addresses for those connections. Understanding and configuring outbound policies is crucial for optimizing performance and reliability in multi-WAN setups.

In a Peplink Balance Two with dual WANs configured, outbound rules can lead to issues when the primary WAN is available but has no internet access, causing all traffic to be affected, including that destined for the secondary WAN. The only solution in such cases is to disable the outbound rules for the primary WAN and the WAN itself in the Peplink UI to restore traffic flow. There is a suggestion for a feature called 'Fall-through to Next Rule' to improve the handling of outbound rules, which is not universally available across all Peplink devices, as some users have experienced difficulties with outbound priority rules on devices like the Surf Soho.

For a Balance 2500 router experiencing a constant high frequency beeping sound, it is suggested that a PSU replacement may be necessary if the router is configured with dual PSUs. The status light on the PSU should be checked, with a normal PSU indicated by a green light. Additionally, the beeping sound can be turned off by pressing the red button located on the rear panel of the Balance 2500.

To address the issue of a Peplink Balance 30 Pro LTE failing to obtain an IP address after switching back from WAN1 to the 4G connection, it is important to check the health check settings configured for the 4G connection. The router is designed to fail back to the primary 4G connection only when it is determined to be healthy, which suggests that adjusting these health check parameters may resolve the problem of the router not fully connecting to the internet after regaining mobile signal.

To manage bandwidth usage and avoid exceeding data caps while using SpeedFusion Cloud to bond two internet connections, it is possible to create an Outbound Policy that redirects specific applications or categories of traffic away from the SpeedFusion tunnel. This allows for selective routing, such as avoiding streaming services like Netflix from using the bonded connection, thus optimizing data usage and taking advantage of other network features like video optimization on cellular networks.

To manage data usage effectively while using SpeedFusion Cloud to bond two internet connections, it is possible to configure outbound policies on Peplink/Pepwave routers. By navigating to Network > Outbound Policy, users can specify which traffic should be directed to specific connections, allowing for the exclusion of certain services, such as Netflix, from the bonded connection to avoid exceeding data caps.

In a network configuration involving PepLink Balance 305 devices connected to a Balance 508 via IP Sec VPN tunnels to Azure, it is noted that IP Sec tunnels do not typically advertise their routes through second hops. To enable connectivity from satellite sites to Azure, a static route for the Azure subnet can be added on the satellite devices, pointing to the Balance 508. Additionally, firewall configurations on both the satellite sites and Azure may need to be reviewed to ensure they allow the necessary traffic exchange.

To enable connectivity from PepLink Balance 305 devices to Azure through a Balance 508, static routes can be configured on the Balance 305 for the Azure subnet, using the Balance 508 as the gateway. Additionally, the Azure configuration should include a static route for the Balance 305 subnet, also using the Balance 508 as the gateway. It is important to ensure that firewall rules on both ends permit this routing to function correctly.

In a network setup involving multiple PepLink Balance 305 devices connected to a Balance 508 via a star topology, issues may arise with route advertisement to Azure through IP Sec VPN tunnels. The Balance 508 may not be advertising its routes to the connected Balance 305 devices, which can prevent satellite sites from accessing Azure. Additionally, static routes may need to connect to gateways within the same subnet, which can complicate configurations if sites are not willing to share a common subnet.

In a network configuration involving multiple PepLink Balance 305 routers connected to a Balance 508 via IP Sec VPN tunnels to Azure, it is important to ensure that outbound rules are correctly set up for traffic to traverse from the satellite sites to Azure. The Balance 508 needs to properly advertise its routes to the connected 305 devices for successful end-to-end connectivity.

The outbound policy configuration on the PepLink Balance 508 was successfully adjusted, allowing the connected Balance 305 devices to traverse to Azure through the established IP Sec VPN tunnels. This indicates that proper routing and policy settings are essential for enabling connectivity between satellite sites and Azure.

When using a Peplink Balance 30 Pro with a Verizon SIM to serve a network of over 100 computers, issues with throughput may arise despite good ping times and download speeds when only a few devices are connected. Potential causes for the low throughput could include the limitations of the Verizon plan being used, as many mobile data plans are not designed for enterprise router use. It is advisable to check traffic statistics to identify if any single device is consuming excessive bandwidth and to conduct tests with fewer devices to isolate the issue.

The Balance 30 LTEA has been updated and renamed to Balance 30 Pro, featuring a new hardware revision that includes CAT6 LTE-Advanced, 802.11ac Wi-Fi, and 4x PoE LAN ports. The classic Balance 30 LTE retains its CAT3 LTE configuration, while the new Balance 30 Pro offers enhanced capabilities with LTE-Advanced technology.

In a Peplink Balance Two setup, if outbound policy is not directing traffic as expected, it may be due to the order of rules. The HTTPS Persistence rule is processed before the default priority rule, leading to traffic being sent to WAN2. To resolve this, one can either set the outbound policy to custom and adjust the ratio for WAN2 to zero, or create a higher priority HTTPS rule for WAN1 that allows fall-through to the next rule if it fails, ensuring that WAN1 is prioritized for HTTPS traffic.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a throughput of 150Mbps, which is less than the combined total of the user's WAN connections (100/5M, 150/6M, and 35/5M). For users with 20-30 connections, particularly for applications like Zoom, upgrading to a Peplink Balance 305 is recommended due to its higher capacity and performance, supporting up to 1Gbps throughput. Alternatively, the Balance 210 with an additional license can provide a maximum throughput of 350Mbps, but it is not as capable as the Balance 305.

Peplink supports Service Passthroughs, and the 8.1 firmware indicates that SIP Passthrough is always enabled. However, the specific implications of NAT Slipstreaming and whether Peplink devices are vulnerable to this attack are currently being investigated by the engineering team.

To activate the optional WAN input on a PEPLINK BALANCE 20 device and connect a third line, a license is required, which costs approximately $50. An article is available that provides guidance on how to activate WAN 3 on the device.

When experiencing issues with a Peplink Balance 30LTE where the cellular connection is stuck on 'Resetting...', it may be related to the SIM card's activation status. If the SIM card was activated on a different device type, such as a tablet, it could cause compatibility issues with the router. In such cases, contacting the carrier's technical support may be necessary to resolve the activation problem.

SpeedFusion operates at the packet level, while Outbound Policy functions at the session level. The bonding algorithm can effectively fill both links equally with proper tweaks to cutoffs. The Dynamic Weighted Balance (DWB) algorithm is noted for its throughput but can be unpredictable, sometimes favoring one link significantly over another. The Lowest Latency option may alternate between links rapidly if they have similar performance. The Overflow option is based on defined bandwidth for connections, but it cannot be applied to cellular links, as it is designed for wired connections only. Users can attempt to set bandwidth on a wired connection to manage overflow to cellular links.

A Peplink balance router can perform session-based load balancing, where a single session is limited by the WAN link it is using, but users will see combined bandwidth across all their sessions. For higher bandwidth utilization, SpeedFusion Bonding allows a single session to be distributed at a packet level across multiple WAN links simultaneously. To implement load balancing, a router like the Balance One is recommended, while SpeedFusion requires a device or service to bond traffic, with the option of using SpeedFusion Cloud for easier setup.

The Peplink Balance 300, which is approximately 15 years old, supports a maximum throughput of 20Mbps. Therefore, if clients are experiencing a maximum speed of 15Mbps, this is within the expected performance limits of the device, despite having three WAN connections with a total potential speed of 300Mbps.

The Balance 300 router supports a maximum throughput of 20mbps per user, despite having three WAN connections each capable of 100mbps. This means that while the total potential speed from the WAN connections is 300mbps, the router's limitations restrict the actual usable speed to 20mbps per user, indicating that the additional bandwidth from the WAN connections is not utilized effectively.

The Peplink Balance 310 has a WAN to LAN router throughput rating of 100 Mbps, which is the sum of simultaneous upload and download speeds across all WAN connections. A fiber optic internet connection with 200 Mbps download speed exceeds the capacity of the Balance 310, potentially leading to undesirable performance issues. However, the newer Balance 210/310 models (HW revision 4) are expected to see a performance increase with the upcoming 6.2.1 firmware.

The Peplink Balance 310 has a specified router throughput of 100Mbps, which refers to its firewall/router capabilities. In contrast, the Balance 210 Hardware version 4 supports a higher firewall/router throughput of 350Mbps and a PepVPN throughput of 80Mbps.

The Peplink B-380 with firmware version 8.0.1 has implemented features that may resolve issues related to establishing GRE tunnels when a Peplink device is included in the network. The previous configuration required for GRE tunnels may no longer be necessary with this updated firmware.

In a Peplink balancer setup with multiple WAN links, weighted load balancing is typically used by default. Users can modify this behavior by implementing outbound policies to control traffic flow according to their specific requirements.

When setting up multiple WAN links in a Peplink balancer, it is common to observe different WAN link paths to the same destination due to the dynamic nature of internet routing. Routes can change frequently as routers adjust their paths, which can be illustrated by performing a traceroute. Peplink may utilize mechanisms such as round-robin for load balancing across these WAN links, but the variability in routing is a general characteristic of the internet.

To set up outbound traffic weight ratios for multiple WAN connections on a Peplink Balance, Weighted Balance rules can be configured to distribute traffic based on the speed of each WAN link. For instance, if WAN1 has a speed of 3M, WAN2 has 2M, and WAN3 has 3M, the load distribution weight should be set as 3:2:3 to allocate more traffic to the faster links. Additionally, for services with different upstream and downstream speeds, such as SMTP, a per-service Weighted Balance rule can be implemented to optimize traffic distribution, for example, using a weight of 1:4:1 based on the upstream capabilities of each WAN link.

The Peplink Balance 20 is designed for small office or branch environments and is recommended for up to 60 users. In larger network environments, using a Balance router with a higher capacity is advisable to prevent interruptions. The Balance 20 may struggle with handling traffic loads effectively, especially when multiple clients are connected and NATed by another router.

To implement traffic management on a Peplink BPL-ONE-CORE with two WAN connections, it is important to note that an overflow rule will take precedence over a lowest latency rule if it is positioned first. It is advisable to use a lowest latency rule, as this will redirect traffic to the WAN with the lowest latency, which can change if the WAN becomes saturated. Additionally, it is crucial to enter the correct available upload and download bandwidth for each WAN in their respective settings to ensure proper functionality of the rules.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a maximum throughput limit of 150Mbps, which is tied to its hardware. To achieve gigabit speeds, users must upgrade to a Balance 305 or a higher model. Future hardware revisions may allow for increased throughput in new models, but currently, there are no upgrade options for the Balance 20 to support higher speeds.

To resolve issues with VOIP phones when using both WAN1 and WAN2 without failover, it is recommended to use Priority mode instead of Enforced mode. In Priority mode, if WAN1 goes down, traffic will automatically switch to WAN2, which can help maintain call quality and prevent call drops.

It is not possible to convert the configuration from a PepLink Balance 310 to a PepLink Balance 210. Additionally, it is important to confirm whether a 3rd WAN activation license has been purchased for the Balance 210 router.

The firmware version 4.1.0 build 1083 on the Peplink Balance 30 classic can be updated to version 4.8.1, and the firmware file can be downloaded from the provided link: https://download.peplink.com/firmware/plb30/fw-b30-4.8.1build1106.bin.

To achieve balanced traffic distribution across two WAN connections on a Peplink Balance 20, the default outbound policy rule, which utilizes the lowest latency algorithm, is generally effective. However, service passthrough support for certain traffic types can override these outbound policy rules and may lead to uneven traffic distribution. Understanding the specific traffic types can assist in configuring the Balance 20 for optimal performance.
The default login credentials for the Peplink Balance 1 router are username 'admin' and password 'admin'.

The Peplink Balance 710 devices are currently running firmware version 5.2.9. Users may encounter an 'Unlock key validation failed' error when attempting to unlock the device using the serial number found on the chassis. This suggests that the serial number may not be correctly associated with the unlock key, or there may be an issue with the firmware or device configuration.

The maximum throughput of the Peplink Balance 310 HW1 is 100 Mbps, and it cannot be upgraded past firmware version 5.x.x. The device is no longer officially supported by Peplink, and upgrading to a newer model is recommended if higher throughput or newer features are desired.

In a Peplink device setup without SpeedFusion VPN, session-based load balancing is utilized across multiple WAN links, such as the weighted balance policy. A download manager can leverage multiple sessions to download a single file, allowing for WAN bandwidth aggregation. However, without a download manager, a single file download session will only utilize one WAN link, limiting the bandwidth to that specific connection.
The Balance 30-20 does not support reverse proxy functionality. However, inbound load balancing is supported on the Balance 210 and above models.

The Peplink Balance 20 has a throughput rating of 150Mbps, which may become a bottleneck given the total WAN bandwidth of 350/250 Mbps. It excels in load balancing in multi-WAN environments and is recommended to use PepVPN/SpeedFusion instead of IPsec for better performance. For redundancy, it is suggested to use the Balance 20 primarily for NAT, as it may not handle the full bandwidth effectively. A configuration option includes using the cable modem on WAN 1 in drop-in mode and connecting the fiber to WAN 2, allowing the Balance to act as an ARP proxy for failover. This setup would provide public IP access from the cable modem while maintaining backup capabilities with the fiber connection.
The latest firmware for the Peplink Balance 20W is v4.8.1, and this model has been obsoleted. Users are advised to consider refreshing their router for updated features and support.

In a Peplink Balance 20 configuration with multiple WAN connections, the default outbound policy should be set to Priority to ensure traffic is routed through the WAN connection with the highest priority that is passing healthchecks. If the policy is set to Lowest Latency, it may not respect the priority order, leading to unexpected data usage on lower priority WANs. Healthchecks should be configured to monitor the connectivity of each WAN, and adjustments to upload and download bandwidth settings can influence which WAN is actively used. Proper configuration of backup priority groups may also be necessary to ensure failover works as intended, with WAN2 acting as a backup to WAN1 and WAN3 as a backup to both.

When using a Peplink Balance 20 with multiple WAN connections, normal internet traffic will load balance between the WANs, which can lead to inconsistent performance during activities like streaming and browsing. Speedtest.net may show higher results because it tests the combined bandwidth of both connections. To configure the device for better performance, users can access the Peplink console at 192.168.1.1 and set outbound policy rules to optimize traffic based on their specific needs.

In a Peplink Balance One setup with two WAN connections, the Overflow load balancing algorithm allows traffic to be routed through the primary WAN connection (WAN2) until it reaches full capacity, at which point new sessions can be routed through the secondary WAN connection (WAN1) if it is not saturated. However, load balancing can lead to unexpected behavior, such as when a task is split into batches, resulting in one WAN connection finishing its tasks while the other continues to process, potentially leading to inefficiencies in overall upload times.

The Peplink 20 utilizes outbound policies for user requests to websites hosted on the Internet, allowing for return traffic via different WAN connections based on the configured policy. Inbound connections, such as an Internet user accessing a website hosted behind the Peplink, depend on the IP address provided by the DNS server, which determines the specific WAN through which the connection will be established.

The Peplink 20 does not support inbound load balancing, meaning inbound traffic is handled on a first-come, first-served basis without prioritization based on connection speed or bandwidth. For outbound traffic, users can select from different policies: 'High Application Compatibility' routes all outbound traffic from the same LAN host to the same WAN connection regardless of destination, while 'Normal Application Compatibility' routes traffic from the same LAN host to the same WAN connection for the same destination IP, allowing for WAN link load balancing when accessing multiple servers.

To achieve desired traffic distribution on a Peplink Balance 305 with multiple WAN connections, changing the Outbound Policy algorithm from 'HTTPS Persistence' to 'Priority' is recommended. This adjustment will ensure that traffic primarily utilizes WAN 1, while also enabling the 'Terminate Sessions on Link Recovery' option to maintain connection on WAN 1 when it recovers from a failure. The current configuration with HTTPS Persistence causes traffic to be distributed across all WANs, leading to an unintended 60/30/10 traffic split.

To manage traffic on a Peplink Balance 20 router and prevent Netflix and torrent traffic from using a satellite connection, outbound policies can be applied based on source IP, destination IP, domain, or application ports. It is suggested to identify the source IP of devices like a smart TV for Netflix and route its traffic through WAN2 (microwave connection) using enforced outbound policies. Similarly, a designated PC for torrents can also be configured to use WAN2. However, care must be taken as other devices may still default to the available WAN connection unless specifically configured otherwise.

To upgrade the firmware on a Peplink Balance 700 from version 4, the device must first be updated to version 4.8.2, then to 5.3.12, and finally to the highest version 5.4.9. Users are advised to open a support ticket for specific links and instructions regarding the firmware upgrade process.

For load balancing between two WAN connections on a Peplink device, the default outbound policy checks for latency. If sessions are not distributed evenly, the weighted balance algorithm can be utilized, allowing for manual configuration with a specific ratio to optimize the distribution of outbound sessions.

When renaming a WAN on a Pepwave device, the new name may not immediately reflect in the event log, which could require a reboot to update. It has been noted that making additional changes related to the WAN after renaming may help in displaying the new name without needing to reboot, as tested on version 6.3.0.

The Peplink Balance 20 can implement a custom HTTPS persistence rule that allows a single source IP to maintain a connection through a designated WAN port, specifically WAN #1. Additionally, it has a default rule that balances traffic equally between WAN #1 and WAN #2, allowing for effective load balancing across multiple WAN connections.

To configure a Peplink Balance 20 for specific application priorities, outbound rules can be set up. For example, a rule can be created for HTTPS traffic (TCP port 443) using an Overflow algorithm with WAN1 as the first priority and WAN2 as the second. A default rule can also be established with WAN2 as the first priority and WAN1 as the second. However, achieving precise control over traffic based on application types like Skype or YouTube may be challenging due to the use of random ports by these services.

To configure a Peplink Balance 20 for specific traffic management, it is possible to set outbound rules that prioritize WAN connections based on the type of traffic. For example, for HTTPS traffic (like Skype), a rule can be created to prioritize WAN1 first and WAN2 second. For general traffic, another rule can prioritize WAN2 first and WAN1 second. The configuration can utilize algorithms such as Overflow and Priority to manage the traffic effectively, but it may require knowledge of specific domains or IPs for precise redirection of services like Skype and YouTube.

For the Pepwave Balance 580 device, MIB files for SNMP v3 can be obtained from the 6.3 device version. Users should ensure their device is running on 6.3 RC to monitor CPU and memory usage effectively. The private MIB files for Balance/MAX 6.3 will be made available for public download shortly.

To address slow download speeds when using a Peplink Balance 20 Router with an ATT DSL service, it is recommended to try setting the connection to 100M Full Duplex (FD) instead of AUTO, as some modems may be sensitive to this setting. Additionally, checking the MTU (Maximum Transmission Unit) setting is important; for DSL connections, it should typically be set to 1492 to optimize performance.

The Balance 310 hardware revision 1 has a throughput rating of 50 Mbps, while the latest revision 3 supports up to 200 Mbps. For inquiries regarding upgrade or replacement programs, contacting Peplink sales directly is recommended.

The Peplink Balance 20 router has a maximum rated throughput of 100 Mbps, which is likely causing the observed throughput limitation when connected to a 250 Mbps cable connection. For higher throughput needs, upgrading to a Peplink Balance One, which supports over 600 Mbps, is recommended.

In a Peplink 580 configured in drop-in mode with WAN 1 and an ADSL line on WAN 2, the default outbound policy uses the Lowest Latency algorithm, which may lead to uneven traffic distribution, especially if most traffic is HTTPS and all users are NATTED behind a firewall. This results in traffic being routed through the same WAN until the session ends. For a more balanced distribution of traffic, it is recommended to change the outbound rule algorithm to Weighted Balance.

Random system startups on Pepwave devices such as the Surf Soho, Balance 20, and Balance One may occur after upgrading to firmware version 6.2.1, as reported by users. The issue does not appear to affect models like the 305 and 380, which are running the same firmware. There is no indication in the logs to suggest a specific cause, as the logs only show a generic 'System: Started up' message.

To configure a Peplink Balance 20 for load balancing and prioritization, use the default Outbound Policy settings with specific adjustments. Set the HTTPS_Persistence Rule to have a custom load distribution with equal weights for WAN1 and WAN2, while others are set to zero. For the Default Rule, use the Overflow algorithm with the order of WAN1, WAN2, and Mobile Internet. Prioritization of traffic can be managed through the QoS settings under Network > QoS > Application, allowing for specific prioritization of email, browsing, Soonr.com, and other traffic types.

To upgrade a Peplink Balance 580 from firmware version 5.3.12, the next available version is 5.4.9, with version 6.2 also available. Upgrading from version 5.x to 6.x requires an unlock key, which can be obtained by ensuring the device is under warranty and opening a support ticket. Release notes for version 6.2 provide information on new features, improvements, and resolved issues, which can be accessed through the provided link.

The Peplink Balance supports seven outbound algorithms for WAN load balancing: Weighted Balance, Persistence, Enforced, Priority, Overflow, Least Used, and Lowest Latency. For a setup where DSL is the primary connection and 4G LTE serves as a failover, the Overflow algorithm is recommended, as it routes traffic through the highest priority healthy WAN connection and switches to the next available connection when the primary is saturated. Additionally, Quality of Service (QoS) features such as Group Bandwidth Reservation and Application Prioritization can be enabled to ensure that work PCs receive priority bandwidth over other applications like Netflix, especially when both are using the DSL connection.

For load balancing and failover of two 15Mb DSL connections with 15 users and 50 devices including VoIP and VPN support, the PepLink Balance 030 may not be adequate as it is recommended for up to 25 simultaneous users/devices. The Balance One is suggested as a more suitable option for this configuration.

To configure a Peplink Balance 20/30 for a network with multiple workstations and servers, the custom outbound policy manager can be utilized to create rules that direct specific workstations to use WAN2 while all other traffic uses WAN1. This can be achieved through the Priority or Enforced algorithm. Additionally, time-based rules for scheduling traffic management have been requested and are on the development roadmap, although no estimated time of arrival (ETA) has been provided.

Peplink lists several USB modems from AT&T that are compatible with their Balance Routers, including models such as the AT&T Mobile Hotspot Elevate 4G, MiFi Liberate, and various Sierra Wireless and LG devices. However, the original post questions the compatibility of newer AT&T products like the AT&T Beam, Unite Pro, Unite, and Velocity with Peplink devices. It is suggested that compatibility may depend on the availability of drivers for these newer dongles.

With Peplink routers running firmware version 6.2, users can utilize seven different load balancing algorithms. For a scenario where ADSL is the primary connection, the Overflow algorithm can be employed to manage traffic effectively. Additionally, users can create specific rules using the enforced or priority algorithm to direct certain traffic, such as streaming services, over the satellite connection. It is important to note that the order of rules in the outbound policy list matters, with more defined rules taking precedence over the Overflow algorithm, which should be placed at the bottom.

To manage internet connectivity on a Peplink Balance One router with two WAN connections, it is suggested to use the Priority Algorithm instead of the Overflow rule. The Overflow rule only reroutes new sessions to the next WAN connection when the primary WAN is saturated, which may not address issues caused by external factors affecting WAN1. Therefore, if WAN1 becomes sluggish due to external interference, the Priority Algorithm can help ensure that WAN2 is utilized more effectively during such conditions.

When experiencing low internet throughput with a Peplink Balance 50 connected to multiple internet connections, it is important to check the router's specifications, particularly the 'Router Throughput' which includes both download and upload speeds. Understanding these limits can help in diagnosing performance issues, especially in a residential setting with multiple clients.

It is possible to perform a configuration conversion between Peplink Balance 300 and Balance 380 devices. Users can send the configuration file from the Balance 300 to Peplink's technical support team for assistance with the conversion process.

The Pepwave routers utilize various load balancing algorithms to manage WAN connections effectively. The Weighted Balance algorithm distributes traffic based on the specified weights of each WAN connection. The Persistence algorithm ensures that traffic from a client computer maintains the same WAN connection for secure services, with modes available for source and destination persistence. The Enforced algorithm routes traffic through a specified WAN connection regardless of its health status. The Priority algorithm uses the highest priority WAN connection available for routing, while the Overflow algorithm routes traffic through the healthiest connection that is not fully loaded. The Least Used algorithm selects the WAN connection with the most available download bandwidth, and the Lowest Latency algorithm routes traffic through the connection with the lowest latency, determined by periodic latency checks.

The Outbound Policy feature in Peplink routers allows users to define how LAN-to-Internet traffic is routed using various algorithms such as Weighted Balance, Persistence, Enforced, Priority, Overflow, Least Used, Lowest Latency, and Fastest Response Time. Each algorithm serves different purposes, such as distributing traffic based on bandwidth, ensuring consistent routing for specific traffic types, or prioritizing connections based on availability. The Fastest Response Time algorithm duplicates traffic across all healthy connections at the start of a session and routes it based on the first response received, making it suitable for time-sensitive applications like VoIP. The configuration of Outbound Policy rules is done through the Peplink UI, where users can specify service names, source and destination metrics, protocols, and algorithms, with options for session termination on link recovery and expert mode for routing outside of SpeedFusion tunnels.

The video discusses various traffic management techniques for optimizing internet connectivity, particularly in relation to SSL traffic and Peplink's SpeedFusion technology. IP persistence ensures that once a connection is established, all traffic remains on that WAN until the session ends, which is crucial for maintaining reliable SSL sessions. Enforced traffic routing allows specific applications, such as Windows updates or guest networks, to use designated internet connections, preventing them from failing over to more expensive options. Priority routing enables the selection of preferred connections based on performance, allowing for failover to backup connections only if the primary fails. The video also touches on the overflow method, which allows for dynamic bandwidth allocation by utilizing a slower connection until it reaches capacity, at which point it can overflow into a faster connection. Lastly, the least used algorithm distributes new sessions across connections based on their current bandwidth usage, optimizing overall throughput.

The video discusses the configuration of outbound policies for managing multiple WAN connections, particularly in a maritime context. It explains the use of priority settings for SIM cards, where a primary SIM card is used first, followed by secondary cards if the primary fails. The three main outbound policies covered are weighted balance, priority, and enforced. Weighted balance allows traffic to be distributed across multiple connections based on defined ratios, which is particularly useful for load balancing in dynamic environments like maritime. Priority routes traffic through the preferred connection as long as it is healthy, while enforced restricts specific traffic to a single defined connection. The video also demonstrates how to create VLANs and outbound policies to manage traffic effectively, ensuring that the best available connection is utilized, whether it be port Wi-Fi, cellular, or satellite, with provisions for failover and load balancing based on connection availability.

The video discusses advanced routing techniques and policies for managing internet connections using Peplink's SpeedFusion technology. It highlights the use of Fastest Response Time routing, which selects the quickest internet connection for each new session, and Overflow, which utilizes connections based on their capacity. Session Persistence ensures that specific traffic, such as SSL connections, remains on the same connection until terminated or failed. The Least Used policy routes traffic based on the least utilized connection, and the firmware version 8.4.0 introduced the ability to choose between least used by upload or download. The video also covers the importance of managing outbound policies in relation to routing protocols like BGP and OSPF, and the use of InControl2 for managing traffic based on destination regions and applications. SpeedFusion requires two compatible units for bonding and offers various configurations such as point-to-point, mesh, and star. Additionally, it details features like bandwidth bonding, WAN smoothing, hot failover, and PepVPN for enhanced connectivity and reliability.

Outbound policies in Peplink are used for traffic shaping and routing, allowing for the configuration of how traffic is directed through WAN connections. These policies operate on a top-down basis, meaning that the order of the policies affects their application. If a default route is being pushed via BGP or OSPF, it can override user-defined traffic shaping protocols unless the policies are reordered appropriately. Peplink's InControl adds features such as priority routing and dynamically updated definitions for cloud applications, which are not available outside of this management platform. The system supports multiple load balancing algorithms, including weighted balance, enforced priority, and least used, with the latter now considering both downlink and uplink bandwidth. query: How can outbound policy rules on Peplink Balance 20/30 series routers be used to direct specific types of traffic or devices to designated WAN connections, and what are the key algorithms, configuration steps, and best practices for optimizing performance and session integrity in multi-WAN environments?
answer: Outbound policy rules on Peplink Balance 20/30 series routers allow administrators to direct specific types of traffic or devices to designated WAN connections, optimizing performance and maintaining session integrity in multi-WAN environments. The process involves configuring the outbound policy manager to use custom rules, where algorithms such as Weighted Balance, Persistence, Enforced, Priority, Overflow, Least Used, and Lowest Latency can be applied based on the desired outcome. For example, rules can be set to route all HTTPS traffic (TCP port 443) from a particular device or IP through a specific WAN using the Persistence or Enforced algorithm, ensuring that return traffic follows the same path and sessions remain stable (critical for services like FTP or SSL). Weighted Balance can distribute traffic proportionally to link speeds, while Priority and Overflow can ensure backup or failover behaviors. Best practices include retaining default rules like HTTPS Persistence, prioritizing rules in the correct order (top-down), and adjusting bandwidth values for each WAN to ensure algorithms function as intended. After creating or modifying rules, changes must be saved and applied. Using outbound policies in this way allows for granular traffic management, prevents session drops caused by IP changes, and ensures optimal use of available bandwidth.

citations.claim: Outbound policy rules can be used to direct specific machines or traffic types to designated WAN connections, ensuring consistent routing for sessions such as FTP.

Outbound policy rules on Balance 20/30 are configured by setting the Outbound Policy to 'Managed by Custom Rules', retaining default rules like HTTPS Persistence, and adding specific rules for traffic from certain LAN clients to designated WANs.
Peplink supports multiple outbound policy algorithms: Weighted Balance, Persistence, Enforced, Priority, Overflow, Least Used, and Lowest Latency, each serving different traffic management purposes.
Weighted Balance distributes traffic according to the speed of each WAN link, while Persistence ensures session integrity by keeping traffic from a client on the same WAN connection.
Priority and Enforced algorithms allow administrators to specify preferred or exclusive WAN usage for certain traffic, facilitating failover or dedicated routing.
Outbound policy rules are processed in top-down order, with higher rules taking precedence, so rule order is critical for effective policy application.
After creating or modifying outbound policy rules, users must save and apply changes for the rules to take effect.
Proper adjustment of bandwidth values for each WAN in the settings is necessary for algorithms like Weighted Balance and Overflow to function correctly.

Outbound policies can help maintain session integrity and prevent issues (like session drops or inconsistent performance) that occur when traffic is not consistently routed through the same WAN, which is especially important for stateful sessions like FTP or SSL.
